documentation: The API for controlling a SolidFire cluster.

types.name: Account
documentation: The object containing information about an account.
This object only includes "configured" information about the account, not any runtime or usage information.

members.name: accountID
members.documentation: Unique AccountID for the account.

members.name: username
members.documentation: User name for the account.

members.name: status
members.documentation: Current status of the account.

members.name: volumes
members.documentation: List of VolumeIDs for Volumes owned by this account.

members.name: initiatorSecret
members.documentation: CHAP secret to use for the initiator.

members.name: targetSecret
members.documentation: CHAP secret to use for the target (mutual CHAP authentication).

members.name: attributes
members.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

enum.documentation: The account can log into volumes.
The account is locked and cannot log into volumes.
The account has been deleted, but is not yet purged from the system.

deprecated.message: Accounts are deleted immediately, to this value is no longer used.

members.name: accountID
members.documentation: AccountID for the newly created Account.

members.name: account
members.documentation: Account details.

members.name: accounts
members.documentation: List of accounts.

types.name: ClusterCapacity
types.documentation: High level capacity measurements for the entire cluster.

members.name: activeBlockSpace
documentation: The amount of space on the block drives.
This includes additional information such as metadata entries and space which can be cleaned up.

members.name: activeSessions
members.documentation: Number of active iSCSI sessions communicating with the cluster

members.name: averageIOPS
members.documentation: Average IPS for the cluster since midnight Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

members.name: clusterRecentIOSize
members.documentation: The average size of IOPS to all volumes in the cluster.

members.name: currentIOPS
members.documentation: Average IOPS for all volumes in the cluster over the last 5 seconds.

members.name: maxIOPS
members.documentation: Estimated maximum IOPS capability of the current cluster.

members.name: maxOverProvisionableSpace
documentation: The maximum amount of provisionable space.
This is a computed value.
You cannot create new volumes if the current provisioned space plus the new volume size would exceed this number:
maxOverProvisionableSpace = maxProvisionedSpace * GetClusterFull

members.name: maxProvisionedSpace
members.documentation: The total amount of provisionable space if all volumes are 100% filled (no thin provisioned metadata).

members.name: maxUsedMetadataSpace
members.documentation: The amount of bytes on volume drives used to store metadata.

members.name: maxUsedSpace
members.documentation: The total amount of space on all active block drives.

members.name: nonZeroBlocks
members.documentation: Total number of 4KiB blocks with data after the last garbage collection operation has completed.

members.name: peakActiveSessions
members.documentation: Peak number of iSCSI connections since midnight UTC.

members.name: peakIOPS
members.documentation: The highest value for currentIOPS since midnight UTC.

members.name: provisionedSpace
members.documentation: Total amount of space provisioned in all volumes on the cluster.

members.name: snapshotNonZeroBlocks
members.documentation: Total number of 4KiB blocks in snapshots with data.

members.name: timestamp
members.documentation: The date and time this cluster capacity sample was taken.

members.name: totalOps
members.documentation: The total number of I/O operations performed throughout the lifetime of the cluster

members.name: uniqueBlocks
documentation: The total number of blocks stored on the block drives.
The value includes replicated blocks.

members.name: uniqueBlocksUsedSpace
documentation: The total amount of data the uniqueBlocks take up on the block drives.
This number is always consistent with the uniqueBlocks value.

members.name: usedMetadataSpace
members.documentation: The total amount of bytes on volume drives used to store metadata

members.name: usedMetadataSpaceInSnapshots
documentation: The amount of bytes on volume drives used for storing unique data in snapshots.
This number provides an estimate of how much metadata space would be regained by deleting all snapshots on the system.

members.name: usedSpace
members.documentation: Total amount of space used by all block drives in the system.

members.name: zeroBlocks
members.documentation: Total number of 4KiB blocks without data after the last round of garabage collection operation has completed.

types.name: ClusterInfo
types.documentation: Cluster Info object returns information the node uses to communicate with the cluster.

members.name: attributes
members.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

members.name: encryptionAtRestState
members.documentation: Encryption at rest state.

members.name: ensemble
members.documentation: Array of Node IP addresses that are participating in the cluster.

members.name: mvip
members.documentation: Management network interface.

members.name: mvipNodeID
members.documentation: Node holding the master MVIP address

members.name: name
members.documentation: Unique cluster name.

members.name: repCount
documentation: Number of replicas of each piece of data to store in the cluster.
Valid value is 2

members.name: svip
members.documentation: Storage virtual IP

members.name: svipNodeID
members.documentation: Node holding the master SVIP address.

members.name: uniqueID
members.documentation: Unique ID for the cluster.

types.name: ClusterVersionInfo
types.documentation: Version information for a node in the cluster.

members.name: cluster
members.documentation: Cluster configuration information the node uses to communicate with the cluster.

types.name: ClusterConfig
types.documentation: Cluster Config object returns information the node uses to communicate with the cluster.

members.name: cipi
members.documentation: Network interface used for cluster communication.

members.name: cluster
members.documentation: Unique cluster name.

members.name: ensemble
members.documentation: Nodes that are participating in the cluster.

members.name: mipi
members.documentation: Network interface used for node management.

members.name: name
members.documentation: Unique cluster name.

members.name: role
members.documentation: Identifies the role of the node

members.name: sipi
members.documentation: Network interface used for storage.

enum.documentation: No alerts or error conditions.
3 nodes of capacity available.
2 nodes of capacity available.
1 node of capacity available. No new volumes or clones can be created.
Completely consumed. Cluster is read-only, iSCSI connection is maintained but all writes are suspended.

members.name: blockFullness
documentation: Current computed level of block fullness of the cluster.

Possible values:
stage1Happy: No alerts or error conditions.
stage2Aware: 3 nodes of capacity available.
stage3Low: 2 nodes of capacity available.
stage4Critical: 1 node of capacity available. No new volumes or clones can be created.
stage5CompletelyConsumed: Completely consumed. Cluster is read-only, iSCSI connection is maintained but all writes are suspended.

members.name: fullness
members.documentation: Reflects the highest level of fullness between "blockFullness" and "metadataFullness".

members.name: maxMetadataOverProvisionFactor
members.documentation: A value representative of the number of times metadata space can be over provisioned relative to the amount of space available. For example, if there was enough metadata space to store 100 TiB of volumes and this number was set to 5, then 500 TiB worth of volumes could be created.

members.name: metadataFullness
members.documentation: Current computed level of metadata fullness of the cluster.

members.name: sliceReserveUsedThresholdPct
members.documentation: Error condition; message sent to "Alerts" if the reserved slice utilization is greater than the sliceReserveUsedThresholdPct value returned.

members.name: stage2AwareThreshold
members.documentation: Awareness condition: Value that is set for "Stage 2" cluster threshold level.

members.name: stage2BlockThresholdBytes
members.documentation: Number of bytes being used by the cluster at which a stage2 condition will exist.

members.name: stage3BlockThresholdBytes
members.documentation: Number of bytes being used by the cluster at which a stage3 condition will exist.

members.name: stage3BlockThresholdPercent
members.documentation: The percent value set for stage3. At this percent full, a warning will be posted in the Alerts log.

members.name: stage3LowThreshold
members.documentation: Error condition; message sent to "Alerts" that capacity on a cluster is getting low.

members.name: stage4CriticalThreshold
members.documentation: Error condition; message sent to "Alerts" that capacity on a cluster is critically low.

members.name: stage4BlockThresholdBytes
members.documentation: Number of bytes being used by the cluster at which a stage4 condition will exist.

members.name: stage5BlockThresholdBytes
members.documentation: Number of bytes being used by the cluster at which a stage5 condition will exist.

members.name: sumTotalClusterBytes
members.documentation: Physical capacity of the cluster measured in bytes.

members.name: sumTotalMetadataClusterBytes
members.documentation: Total amount of space that can be used to store metadata.

members.name: sumUsedClusterBytes
members.documentation: Number of bytes used on the cluster.

members.name: sumUsedMetadataClusterBytes
members.documentation: Amount of space used on volume drives to store metadata.

members.name: blockFullness
documentation: Current computed level of block fullness of the cluster.

Possible values:
stage1Happy: No alerts or error conditions.
stage2Aware: 3 nodes of capacity available.
stage3Low: 2 nodes of capacity available.
stage4Critical: 1 node of capacity available. No new volumes or clones can be created.
stage5CompletelyConsumed: Completely consumed. Cluster is read-only, iSCSI connection is maintained but all writes are suspended.

members.name: fullness
members.documentation: Reflects the highest level of fullness between "blockFullness" and "metadataFullness".

members.name: maxMetadataOverProvisionFactor
members.documentation: A value representative of the number of times metadata space can be over provisioned relative to the amount of space available. For example, if there was enough metadata space to store 100 TiB of volumes and this number was set to 5, then 500 TiB worth of volumes could be created.

members.name: metadataFullness
members.documentation: Current computed level of metadata fullness of the cluster.

members.name: sliceReserveUsedThresholdPct
members.documentation: Error condition; message sent to "Alerts" if the reserved slice utilization is greater than the sliceReserveUsedThresholdPct value returned.

members.name: stage2AwareThreshold
members.documentation: Awareness condition: Value that is set for "Stage 2" cluster threshold level.

members.name: stage2BlockThresholdBytes
members.documentation: Number of bytes being used by the cluster at which a stage2 condition will exist.

members.name: stage3BlockThresholdBytes
members.documentation: Number of bytes being used by the cluster at which a stage3 condition will exist.

members.name: stage3BlockThresholdPercent
members.documentation: The percent value set for stage3. At this percent full, a warning will be posted in the Alerts log.

members.name: stage3LowThreshold
members.documentation: Error condition; message sent to "Alerts" that capacity on a cluster is getting low.

members.name: stage4CriticalThreshold
members.documentation: Error condition; message sent to "Alerts" that capacity on a cluster is critically low.

members.name: stage4BlockThresholdBytes
members.documentation: Number of bytes being used by the cluster at which a stage4 condition will exist.

members.name: stage5BlockThresholdBytes
members.documentation: Number of bytes being used by the cluster at which a stage5 condition will exist.

members.name: sumTotalClusterBytes
members.documentation: Physical capacity of the cluster measured in bytes.

members.name: sumTotalMetadataClusterBytes
members.documentation: Total amount of space that can be used to store metadata.

members.name: sumUsedClusterBytes
members.documentation: Number of bytes used on the cluster.

members.name: sumUsedMetadataClusterBytes
members.documentation: Amount of space used on volume drives to store metadata.

members.name: nodeID
members.documentation: ID of the master node.

members.name: clusterUtilization
members.documentation: The amount of cluster capacity being utilized.

members.name: readBytes
members.documentation: Total bytes read by clients.

members.name: readOps
members.documentation: Total read operations.

members.name: timestamp
members.documentation: Current time in UTC format. ISO 8601 date string.

members.name: writeBytes
members.documentation: Total bytes written by clients.

members.name: writeOps
members.documentation: Total write operations.

members.name: clusterAdmins
members.documentation: Information about the cluster admin.

members.name: clusterAdmin
members.documentation: Information about all cluster and LDAP administrators that exist for a cluster.

members.name: attributes
members.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

members.name: clusterAdminID
members.documentation: ClusterAdminID for the newly created Cluster Admin.

members.name: cluster
members.documentation: Settings for the cluster. All new and current settings are returned.

members.name: networks
members.documentation: List of networks and what type of access they have to the SNMP servers running on the cluster nodes. Present if SNMP v3 is disabled.

members.name: usmUsers
members.documentation: List of users and the type of access they have to the SNMP servers running on the cluster nodes. Present if SNMP v3 is enabled.

members.name: trapRecipients
members.documentation: List of hosts that are to receive the traps generated by the cluster.

members.name: clusterFaultTrapsEnabled
members.documentation: If "true", when a cluster fault is logged a corresponding solidFireClusterFaultNotification is sent to the configured list of trap recipients.

members.name: clusterFaultResolvedTrapsEnabled
members.documentation: If "true", when a cluster fault is logged a corresponding solidFireClusterFaultResolvedNotification is sent to the configured list of trap recipients.

members.name: clusterEventTrapsEnabled
members.documentation: If "true", when a cluster fault is logged a corresponding solidFireClusterEventNotification is sent to the configured list of trap recipients.

members.name: host
members.documentation: The IP address or host name of the target network management station.

members.name: community
members.documentation: SNMP community string.

members.name: port
members.documentation: The UDP port number on the host where the trap is to be sent. Valid range is 1 - 65535. 0 (zero) is not a valid port number. Default is 162.

members.name: networks
documentation: List of networks and access types enabled for SNMP.
Note: "networks" will only be present if SNMP V3 is disabled.

members.name: enabled
members.documentation: If the nodes in the cluster are configured for SNMP.

members.name: snmpV3Enabled
members.documentation: If the nodes in the cluster are configured for SNMP v3.

members.name: usmUsers
members.documentation: If SNMP v3 is enabled, the values returned is a list of user access parameters for SNMP information from the cluster. This will be returned instead of the "networks" parameter.

members.name: enabled
members.documentation: If the nodes in the cluster are configured for SNMP.

members.name: snmpV3Enabled
members.documentation: If the node in the cluster is configured for SNMP v3.

members.name: broadcastclient
members.documentation: If the nodes in the cluster are listening for broadcast NTP messages.

members.name: servers
members.documentation: List of NTP servers.

members.name: cluster
members.documentation: Name of the cluster.

members.name: state
members.documentation:
Available: Node has not been configured with a cluster name.
Pending: Node is pending for a specific named cluster and can be added.
Active: Node is active and a member of a cluster and may not be added to another cluster.

members.name: details
documentation: The details of the support bundle. Values returned in 'details':
bundleName- The name specified in the 'CreateSupportBundle API method. If no name was specified, 'supportbundle' will be used.
extraArgs- The arguments passed with this method.
files- A list of the support bundle files that were created.
output- The command line output from the script that creates the support bundle.
timeoutSec- The timeout specified for the support bundle creation process.
url- URL to the support bundle created.

members.name: duration
documentation: The amount of time required to create the support bundle in the format HH:MM:SS.ssssss

members.name: result
documentation: Whether the support bundle creation passed of failed.

members.name: details
documentation: The details of the support bundle.

members.name: duration
documentation: The amount of time required to create the support bundle in the format HH:MM:SS.ssssss

members.name: result
documentation: Whether the support bundle creation passed of failed.

members.name: bundleName
documentation: The name specified in the 'CreateSupportBundle API method. If no name was specified, 'supportbundle' will be used.

members.name: extraArgs
documentation: The arguments passed with this method.

members.name: files
documentation: A list of the support bundle files that were created.

members.name: url
documentation: The URL that you can use to download the bundle file(s). Should correspond 1:1 with files list.

members.name: output
documentation:
The commands that were run and their output, with newlines replaced by HTML
elements.

members.name: timeoutSec

types.name: AsyncResult
documentation: The wrapped object returned by the "GetAsyncResult" API Service call.
Note: The return value of GetAsyncResult is essentially a nested version of the standard JSON response with an additional status field.

members.name: message
documentation: The return value for the original method call if the call was completed successfully.

enum.documentation: The method is still running.
The method is complete and the result or error is available.

types.name: GetAsyncResultResult
documentation: The object returned by the "GetAsyncResult" API Service call.
Note: The return value of GetAsyncResult is essentially a nested version of the standard JSON response with an additional status field.

members.name: result
documentation: The resulting message for the original method call if the call was completed successfully.

members.name: status
documentation: Status of the asynchronous method call
running: The method is still running.
complete: The method is complete and the result or error is available.

types.name: Attributes
documentation: A JSON object whose maximum serialized size is 1KiB.
Attributes are useful for defining custom properties on many of the system components.

types.name: Hashtable
documentation: A Hashtable with nested Hashtables representing the json result.

types.name: Checksum
documentation: A hash value from some operation.

enum.documentation: Encryption at rest is being enabled.
Encryption at rest is enabled.
Encryption at rest is being disabled.
Encryption at rest is disabled.

types.name: NetworkInterfaceName
types.documentation: The name of a network interface (for example: "Bond10G").

types.name: QoS
documentation: Quality of Service (QoS) values are used on SolidFire volumes to provision performance expectations.
Minimum, maximum and burst QoS values can be set within the ranges specified in the QoS table below.
Volumes created without specified QoS values are created with the Default values listed below.
Default values can be found by running the GetDefaultQoS method.
minIOPS Min: 100/50 (v7.0/v8.0), Default: 100, Max: 15,000
burstIOPS Min: 100/50 (v7.0/v8.0), Default: 15,000, Max: 100,000

members.name: minIOPS
documentation: Desired minimum 4KB IOPS to guarantee.
The allowed IOPS will only drop below this level if all volumes have been capped
at their minimum IOPS value and there is still insufficient performance capacity.

members.name: maxIOPS
documentation: Desired maximum 4KB IOPS allowed over an extended period of time.

members.name: burstIOPS
documentation: Maximum "peak" 4KB IOPS allowed for short periods of time.
Allows for bursts of I/O activity over the normal max IOPS value.

members.name: burstTime
documentation: The length of time burst IOPS is allowed.
The value returned is represented in time units of seconds.
Note: this value is calculated by the system based on IOPS set for QoS.

types.name: VolumeQOS
documentation: Quality of Service (QoS) Result values are used on SolidFire volumes to provision performance expectations.

members.name: minIOPS
documentation: Desired minimum 4KB IOPS to guarantee.
The allowed IOPS will only drop below this level if all volumes have been capped
at their min IOPS value and there is still insufficient performance capacity.

members.name: maxIOPS
documentation: Desired maximum 4KB IOPS allowed over an extended period of time.

members.name: burstIOPS
documentation: Maximum "peak" 4KB IOPS allowed for short periods of time.
Allows for bursts of I/O activity over the normal max IOPS value.

members.name: burstTime
documentation: The length of time burst IOPS is allowed.
The value returned is represented in time units of seconds.
Note: this value is calculated by the system based on IOPS set for QoS.

members.name: curve
documentation: The curve is a set of key-value pairs.
The keys are I/O sizes in bytes.
The values represent the cost performing an IOP at a specific I/O size.
The curve is calculated relative to a 4096 byte operation set at 100 IOPS.

members.name: driveID
documentation: A unique identifier for this drive.

members.name: nodeID
documentation: The node this drive is located.
If the drive has been physically removed from the node, this is where it was last seen.

members.name: assignedService
documentation: If this drive is hosting a service, the identifier for that service.

members.name: asyncResultIDs
documentation: The list of asynchronous jobs currently running on the drive (for example: a secure erase job).

members.name: capacity
documentation: The raw capacity of this drive in bytes.

members.name: serial
members.documentation: The manufacturer's serial number for this drive.

members.name: slot
documentation: Slot number in the server chassis where this drive is located.
If the drive has been physically removed from the node, this will not have a value.

members.name: driveStatus
members.documentation: The current status of this drive.

members.name: driveType
members.documentation: The type of this drive.

members.name: attributes
members.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

types.name: DriveSerial
documentation: A manufacturer-provided serial number.
It is unique to all drives in the world.
The drive is present, but not hosting a service.
It can be added to the cluster with AddDrives.
The drive is hosting data for a service.
The drive is in the process of being secure erased.
Any data on that drive is permanently removed.
The drive is in the process of being removed.
Any data on the drive is being migrated to other active drives in the cluster.
The drive has failed.
Any data that was previously on the drive has been migrated to other drives in the cluster.

enum.documentation: A drive storing volume metadata.
A drive storing block data.
The drive is not active, so its type has yet to be determined.

members.name: driveID
documentation: A unique identifier for this drive.

members.name: capacity
documentation: Total capacity of the drive, in bytes.

members.name: driveID
members.documentation: DriveID for this drive.

members.name: nodeID
members.documentation: NodeID where this drive is located.

members.name: serial
members.documentation: Drive serial number.

members.name: slot
members.documentation: Slot number in the server chassis where this drive is located, or -1 if SATADimm used for internal metadata drive.

enum.documentation: An available drive.
An active drive.
A drive is in the process of being secure erased. Any data on that drive is permanently removed.
A drive that has failed. Any data that was previously on the drive has been migrated to other drives in the cluster.
A drive is in the process of being removed. Any data previously on the drive is being migrated to other drives in the cluster.
Stores volume metadata.
Stores block data.
Drive type not yet active and is yet to be determined.

members.name: attributes
documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

members.name: driveConfig
documentation: Configuration information for the drives that are connected to the cluster

members.name: drives
members.documentation: Information for the drives that are connected to the cluster.

members.name: fibreChannelPorts
members.documentation: List of all physical Fibre Channel ports.

types.name: FibreChannelPortInfo
documentation: Fibre Channel Node Port Info object returns information about all Fibre Channel ports on a node, or for one node in the cluster. The same information is returned for all ports or port information for one node. This information is returned with the API method ListNodeFibreChannelPortInfo (in the SolidFire API Guide).

members.name: firmware
members.documentation: The version of the firmware installed on the Fibre Channel port.

members.name: hbaPort
members.documentation: The ID of the individual HBA port.

members.name: model
members.documentation: Model of the HBA on the port.

members.name: nPortID
members.documentation: Unique SolidFire port node ID.

members.name: pciSlot
members.documentation: Slot in which the pci card resides on the Fibre Channel node hardware.

members.name: serial
members.documentation: Serial number on the Fibre Channel port.

members.name: speed
members.documentation: Speed of the HBA on the port.

members.name: state
documentation: Possible values:

Unknown
NotPresent
Online
Offline
Blocked
Bypassed
Diagnostics
Linkdown
Error
Loopback
Deleted

members.name: switchWwn
members.documentation: The World Wide Name of the Fibre Channel switch port.

members.name: wwnn
members.documentation: World Wide Node Name of the HBA node.

members.name: wwpn
members.documentation: World Wide Port Name assigned to the physical port of the HBA.

members.name: nodes
members.documentation: List of fibre channel port info results grouped by node.

types.name: Slot
documentation: The slot number in the server chassis where a drive is located.
The special value -1 is used if the drive is a SATADimm used for internal metadata drive.

members.name: ldapConfiguration
documentation: List of the current LDAP configuration settings. This API call will not return the plain text of the search account password.

Note: If LDAP authentication is currently disabled, all the returned settings will be empty with the exception of "authType", and "groupSearchType" which are set to "SearchAndBind" and "ActiveDirectory" respectively.

members.name: groups
documentation: List of LDAP groups that the tested user is a member of.

members.name: userDN
documentation: The tested user's full LDAP distinguished name.

types.name: LdapConfiguration

members.name: authType
documentation: Identifies which user authentcation method will be used.
Valid values:
DirectBind
SearchAndBind

members.name: enabled
documentation: Identifies whether or not the system is enabled for LDAP.
Valid values:
true
false

members.name: groupSearchBaseDN
documentation: The base DN of the tree to start the group search (will do a subtree search from here).

members.name: groupSearchCustomFilter
documentation: The custom search filter used.

members.name: groupSearchType
documentation: Controls the default group search filter used, can be one of the following:
NoGroups: No group support.
ActiveDirectory: Nested membership of all of a user's AD groups.
MemberDN: MemberDN style groups (single-level).

members.name: searchBindDN
documentation: A fully qualified DN to log in with to perform an LDAP search for the user (needs read access to the LDAP directory).

members.name: serverURIs
documentation: A comma-separated list of LDAP server URIs (examples: "ldap://1.2.3.4" and ldaps://1.2.3.4:123")

members.name: userDNTemplate
documentation: A string that is used to form a fully qualified user DN.

members.name: userSearchBaseDN
documentation: The base DN of the tree used to start the search (will do a subtree search from here).

members.name: userSearchFilter
documentation: The LDAP filter used.
LDAP Configuration object returns information about the LDAP configuration on SolidFire storage. LDAP information is returned with the API method GetLdapConfiguration.

members.name: loginSessionInfo
documentation: The authentication expiration period. Formatted in H:mm:ss. For example: 1:30:00, 20:00, 5:00. All leading zeros and colons are removed regardless of the format the timeout was entered.
Objects returned are:
timeout - The time, in minutes, when this session will timeout and expire.

members.name: remoteHosts
documentation: List of hosts to forward logging information to.

members.name: host
members.documentation: Hostname or IP address of the log server.

members.name: port
members.documentation: Port number that the log server is listening on.

members.name: nodeID
members.documentation: The ID of the node.

members.name: address
members.documentation: IP address of the network.

members.name: broadcast
members.documentation: Address of NTP broadcast.

members.name: macAddress
members.documentation: Address used to configure the interface.

members.name: mtu
members.documentation: Packet size on the network interface.

members.name: name
members.documentation: Name of the network interface.

members.name: netmask
members.documentation: Netmask for the network interface.

members.name: status
members.documentation: Status of the network.

members.name: type
members.documentation: The type of network, ie, BondMaster.

members.name: virtualNetworkTag
members.documentation: Virtual Network Tag if on virtual network.

types.name: Node
documentation: A node refers to an individual machine in a cluster.
Each active node hosts a master service, which is responsible for managing the drives and other services on its node.
After a node is made active, its drives will become available for addition to the cluster.

members.name: nodeID
documentation: The unique identifier for this node.

members.name: associatedMasterServiceID
documentation: The master service responsible for controlling other services on this node.

members.name: platformInfo
members.documentation: Information about the platform this node is.

members.name: softwareVersion
members.documentation: The version of SolidFire software this node is currently running.

members.name: cip
members.documentation: IP address used for both intra- and inter-cluster communication.

members.name: cipi
members.documentation: The machine's name for the "cip" interface.

members.name: mip
documentation: IP address used for cluster management (hosting the API and web site).

members.name: mipi
members.documentation: The machine's name for the "mip" interface.

members.name: sip
documentation: IP address used for iSCSI traffic.

members.name: sipi
members.documentation: The machine's name for the "sip" interface.

members.name: uuid
members.documentation: UUID of node.

enum.documentation: Node has not been configured with a cluster name.
Node is pending for specific named cluster and can be added.
Node is active and a member of a cluster and may not be added to another cluster.

types.name: PendingNode
documentation: A "pending node" is one that has not yet joined the cluster.
It can be added to a cluster using the AddNode method.

members.name: name
members.documentation: The host name for this node.

members.name: platformInfo
members.documentation: Information about the platform this node is.

members.name: cip
documentation: IP address used for both intra- and inter-cluster communication.

members.name: cipi
members.documentation: The machine's name for the "cip" interface.

members.name: mip

enum.documentation: A healthy service is the normal operating mode.

documentation: The service is not commuicating properly with other services in the cluster.
If it does not resume communication soon, it will be removed.
The service has been removed via the API and is currently being migrated away from.
When its responsibility for hosting volumes have been completely migrated to other services, it will be decommissioned.
This value is only applicable to services with "serviceType"="slice".
Similar to "forcedMigratingSlices", but the service has been "unhealthy" for too long and is being removed from the cluster.
The service no longer has any responsibility for hosting and will be removed from the system soon.

types.name: Snapshot
documentation: Snapshots is an object containing information about each snapshot made for a volume.
The return object includes information for the active snapshot as well as each snapshot created for the volume.

members.name: snapshotID
members.documentation: Unique ID for this snapshot.

members.name: volumeID
members.documentation: The volume this snapshot was taken of.

members.name: name
documentation: A name for this snapshot.
It is not necessarily unique.

members.name: checksum
documentation: A string that represents the correct digits in the stored snapshot.
This checksum can be used later to compare other snapshots to detect errors in the data.

members.name: enableRemoteReplication
members.documentation: Identifies if snapshot is enabled for remote replication.

members.name: expirationReason
documentation: Indicates how the snapshot expiration was set. Possible values:
api: expiration time was set by using the API.
none: there is no expiration time set.
test: expiration time was set for testing.

members.name: expirationTime
members.documentation: The time at which this snapshot will expire and be purged from the cluster.

members.name: remoteStatuses
documentation: Current remote status of the snapshot remoteStatus: Possible values:
Present: Snapshot exists on a remote cluster
Not Present: Snapshot does not exist on remote cluster
Syncing: This is a target cluster and it is currently replicating the snapshot
Deleted: This is a target cluster, the snapshot has been deleted, and it still exists on the source.
volumePairUUID: universal identifier of the volume pair

members.name: status
documentation: Current status of the snapshot
Preparing: A snapshot that is being prepared for use and is not yet writable.
Done: A snapshot that has finished being prepared and is now usable.
Active: This snapshot is the active branch.

members.name: SnapshotUUID
members.documentation: Universal Unique ID of an existing snapshot.

members.name: totalSize
documentation: Total size of this snapshot in bytes.
It is equivalent to totalSize of the volume when this snapshot was taken.

members.name: groupID
documentation: If present, the ID of the group this snapshot is a part of.
If not present, this snapshot is not part of a group.

members.name: groupSnapshotUUID
documentation: The current "members" results contains information about each snapshot in the group.
Each of these members will have a "uuid" parameter for the snapshot's UUID.

members.name: createTime
members.documentation: The time this snapshot was taken.

members.name: attributes
members.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

types.name: GroupSnapshot

members.name: groupSnapshotUUID

members.name: members

members.name: name

members.name: createTime
members.documentation: The UTC formatted day and time on which the snapshot was created.

members.name: status
documentation: Status of the snapshot.
Possible values:
Preparing: A snapshot that is being prepared for use and is not yet writable.
Done: A snapshot that has finished being prepared and is now usable

members.name: attributes
members.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

enum.documentation: Expiration time was set by using the API.
there is no expiration time set.
expiration time was set for testing.
Snapshot exists on a remote cluster
Snapshot does not exist on remote cluster
This is a target cluster and it is currently replicating the snapshot
This is a target cluster, the snapshot has been deleted, and it still exists on the source.
The snapshot is done and is writable (the active branch of the slice).
The snapshot is done and is writable (the active branch of the slice).
The status is unknown.
The snapshot is being created.
The snapshot has completed and is saved.
The snapshot is done and is writable (the active branch of the slice).

members.documentation: ID of the newly-created snapshot.

members.name: checksum
documentation: A string that represents the correct digits in the stored snapshot.
This checksum can be used later to compare other snapshots to detect errors in the data.

The snapshotID passed must be a snapshot on the given volume.

documentation: A string that represents the correct digits in the stored snapshot.
This checksum can be used later to compare other snapshots to detect errors in the data.

members.name: snapshots
documentation: Information about each snapshot for each volume.
If volumeID is not provided, all snapshots for all volumes is returned.
Snapshots that are in a group will be returned with a "groupID".
Snapshots that are enabled for replication.

types.name: Schedule

members.name: attributes
documentation: Indicates the frequency of the schedule occurrence.
Valid values are:
Day of Week
Day of Month
Time Interval

members.name: hasError
documentation: Indicates whether or not the schedule has errors.

members.name: hours
documentation: Shows the hours that will elapse before the next snapshot is created.
Valid values are: 0 - 24

members.name: lastRunStatus
documentation: Indicates the status of the last scheduled snapshot.
Valid values are:
Success
Failed

members.name: lastRunTimeStart
documentation: Indicates the last time the schedule started n ISO 8601 date string.
Valid values are:
Success
Failed

members.name: minutes
documentation: Shows the minutes that will elapse before the next snapshot is created.
Valid values are: 0 - 59

members.name: monthdays
documentation: Shows the days of the month that the next snapshot will be created on.
Valid values are: 0 - 31

members.name: paused
documentation: Indicates whether or not the schedule is paused.

members.name: recurring
documentation: Indicates whether or not the schedule is recurring.

members.name: runNextInterval
documentation: Indicates whether or not the schedule will run the next time the scheduler is active. When set to "true", the schedule will run the next time the scheduler is active and then reset back to "false".

members.name: scheduleID
documentation: Unique ID of the schedule

members.name: scheduleInfo
documentation: Includes the unique name given to the schedule, the retention period for the snapshot that was created, and the volume ID of the volume from which the snapshot was created.

members.name: scheduleName
documentation: Unique name assigned to the schedule.

members.name: scheduleType
documentation: Only "snapshot" is supported at this time.

members.name: startingDate
documentation: Indicates the date the first time the schedule began of will begin. Formatted in UTC time.

members.name: toBeDeleted
documentation: Indicates if the schedule is marked for deletion.

members.name: weekdays
documentation: Indicates the days of the week that a snapshot will be made.

types.documentation: Schedule is an object containing information about each schedule created to autonomously make a snapshot of a volume. The return object includes information for all schedules. If scheduleID is used to identify a specific schedule then only information for that scheduleID is returned. Schedules information is returned with the API method, see ListSchedules on the SolidFire API guide page 245.

types.name: TimePoint
documentation: An absolute point in time on Earth, expressed in UTC.
The format is ISO 8601:2004 combined date time in Zulu time format with microsecond precision.
The seconds portion will only exceed 60 if the time point is during a leap second.
"YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.ssssssZ"

types.name: Duration
documentation: Time durations are in a custom format with microsecond precision.
Fields are never omitted (even if they are 0).
The seconds and minutes fields will never exceed 60, but the hours do not have a limit.
For negative durations, a single '-' is used as a prefix to the output.
H:mm:ss.ssssss

types.name: Volume
documentation: Volumes Info is an object containing information about a volume.
The return objects only include "configured" information about the volume and not runtime or usage information.
Information about paired volumes will also be returned.

members.name: volumeID
members.documentation: Unique VolumeID for the volume.

members.name: name
members.documentation: Name of the volume as provided at creation time.

members.name: accountID
members.documentation: Unique AccountID for the account.

members.name: createTime
members.documentation: UTC formatted time the volume was created.

members.name: status
documentation: Current status of the volume
init: A volume that is being initialized and is not ready for connections.
active: An active volume ready for connections.

members.name: access
documentation: Access allowed for the volume
readOnly: Only read operations are allowed.
readWrite: Reads and writes are allowed.
locked: No reads or writes are allowed.
replicationTarget: Designated as a target volume in a replicated volume pair.

members.name: enable512e
members.documentation: If "true", the volume provides 512 byte sector emulation.

members.name: iqn
members.documentation: Volume iSCSI Qualified Name.

members.name: scsiEUIDeviceID
members.documentation: Globally unique SCSI device identifier for the volume in EUI-64 based 16-byte format.

members.name: scsiNAADeviceID
members.documentation: Globally unique SCSI device identifier for the volume in NAA IEEE Registered Extended format.

members.name: qos
members.documentation: Quality of service settings for this volume.

members.name: volumeAccessGroups
members.documentation: List of volume access groups to which a volume belongs.

members.name: volumePairs
documentation: Information about a paired volume.
Available only if a volume is paired.
@see VolumePairs for return values.

members.name: deleteTime
documentation: The time this volume was deleted.
If this has no value, the volume has not yet been deleted.

members.name: purgeTime
documentation: The time this volume will be purged from the system.
If this has no value, the volume has not yet been deleted (and is not scheduled for purging).

members.name: sliceCount
documentation: The number of slices backing this volume.
In the current software, this value will always be 1.

members.name: totalSize
documentation: Total size of this volume in bytes.

members.name: blockSize
documentation: Size of the blocks on the volume.

members.name: virtualVolumeID
documentation: Virtual volume ID this volume backs.

members.name: attributes
members.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

members.name: mode
documentation: Volume replication mode.
Possible values:
Async: Writes are acknowledged when they complete locally. The cluster does not wait for writes to be replicated to the target cluster.
Sync: Source acknowledges write when the data is stored locally and on the remote cluster.
SnapshotsOnly: Only snapshots created on the source cluster will be replicated. Active writes from the source volume will not be replicated.

members.name: pauseLimit
members.documentation: The number of occurring write ops before auto-pausing, on a per volume pair level.

members.name: remoteServiceID
members.documentation: The remote slice service ID.

members.name: resumeDetails
members.documentation: Reserved for future use.

members.name: snapshotReplication
members.documentation: The details of snapshot replication.

members.name: state
members.documentation: The state of the volume replication.

members.name: stateDetails
members.documentation: Reserved for future use.

members.name: state
members.documentation: The state of the snapshot replication.

members.name: stateDetails
members.documentation: Reserved for future use.

enum.documentation: Only read operations are allowed.
Reads and writes are allowed.
No reads or writes are allowed.

types.documentation: Contains statistical data for an individual volume.

members.name: accountID
members.documentation: AccountID of the volume owner.

members.name: actualIOPS
members.documentation: Current actual IOPS to the volume in the last 500 milliseconds.

members.name: asyncDelay
documentation: The length of time since the volume was last synced with the remote cluster.
If the volume is not paired, this is null.
Note: A target volume in an active replication state always has an async delay of 0 (zero).
Target volumes are system-aware during replication and assume async delay is accurate at all times.

members.name: averageIOPSize
members.documentation: Average size in bytes of recent I/O to the volume in the last 500 milliseconds.

members.name: burstIOPSCredit
documentation: The total number of IOP credits available to the user.
When users are not using up to the max IOPS, credits are accrued.

members.name: clientQueueDepth
members.documentation: The number of outstanding read and write operations to the cluster.

members.name: desiredMetadataHosts
documentation: The volume services being migrated to if the volume metadata is getting migrated between volume services.
A "null" value means the volume is not migrating.

members.name: latencyUSec
documentation: The observed latency time, in microseconds, to complete operations to a volume.
A "0" (zero) value means there is no I/O to the volume.

members.name: metadataHosts
members.documentation: The volume services on which the volume metadata resides.

members.name: nonZeroBlocks
members.documentation: The number of 4KiB blocks with data after the last garbage collection operation has completed.

members.name: readBytes
members.documentation: Total bytes read by clients.

members.name: readLatencyUSec
members.documentation: The average time, in microseconds, to complete read operations.

members.name: readOps
members.documentation: Total read operations.

members.name: throttle
documentation: A floating value between 0 and 1 that represents how much the system is throttling clients
below their max IOPS because of re-replication of data, transient errors and snapshots taken.

members.name: timestamp
members.documentation: The current time in UTC.

members.name: totalLatencyUSec
members.documentation: The average time, in microseconds, to complete read and write operations to a volume.

members.name: unalignedReads
documentation: For 512e volumes, the number of read operations that were not on a 4k sector boundary.
High numbers of unaligned reads may indicate improper partition alignment.

members.name: unalignedWrites
documentation: For 512e volumes, the number of write operations that were not on a 4k sector boundary.
High numbers of unaligned writes may indicate improper partition alignment.

members.name: volumeAccessGroups
members.documentation: List of volume access group(s) to which a volume belongs.

members.name: volumeID
members.documentation: Volume ID of the volume.

members.name: volumeSize
members.documentation: Total provisioned capacity in bytes.

members.name: volumeUtilization
documentation: A floating value that describes how much the client is using the volume.
Values:
0 = Client is not using the volume
1 = Client is using their max
>1 = Client is using their burst

members.name: writeBytes
members.documentation: Total bytes written by clients.

members.name: writeLatencyUSec
members.documentation: The average time, in microseconds, to complete write operations.

members.name: writeOps
members.documentation: Total write operations occurring on the volume.

members.name: zeroBlocks
members.documentation: Total number of 4KiB blocks without data after the last round of garbage collection operation has completed.

enum.documentation: The volume has been created, but is not yet ready for access.
The volume is ready for access.
The volume has been deleted, but not purged.

members.name: volumeID
members.documentation: VolumeID for the newly created volume.

members.name: curve
documentation: The curve is a set of key-value pairs.
The keys are I/O sizes in bytes.
The values represent the cost performing an IOP at a specific I/O size.
The curve is calculated relative to a 4096 byte operation set at 100 IOPS.

members.name: qos
members.documentation: Default QoS values.

members.name: compression
documentation: The amount of space being saved by compressing data on a single volume.
Stated as a ratio where "1" means data has been stored without being compressed.

members.name: deduplication
documentation: The amount of space being saved on a single volume by not duplicating data.
Stated as a ratio.

members.name: missingVolumes
documentation: The volumes that could not be queried for efficiency data.
Missing volumes can be caused by GC being less than hour old, temporary network loss or restarted services since the GC cycle.

members.name: thinProvisioning
documentation: The ratio of space used to the amount of space allocated for storing data.
Stated as a ratio.

members.name: timestamp
members.documentation: The last time efficiency data was collected after Garbage Collection (GC).

members.name: volumeStats
members.documentation: Volume activity information.

members.name: volumes
members.documentation: List of active volumes.

members.name: bulkVolumeJobs
members.documentation: An array of information for each bulk volume job.

members.name: volumes
members.documentation: List of deleted volumes.

members.name: volumes
members.documentation: List of volumes.

members.name: volumes
members.documentation: List of volumes.

members.name: volumeStats
documentation: List of account activity information.
Note: The volumeID member is 0 for each entry, as the values represent the summation of all volumes owned by the account.

members.name: volumeStats
documentation: List of account activity information.

members.name: volumeStats
documentation: List of account activity information.
Note: The volumeID member is 0 for each entry, as the values represent the summation of all volumes owned by the account.

members.name: curve
documentation: The curve is a set of key-value pairs.
The keys are I/O sizes in bytes.
The values represent the cost performing an IOP at a specific I/O size.
The curve is calculated relative to a 4096 byte operation set at 100 IOPS.

members.name: volumeID
members.documentation: Required parameter for "volumes" array: volumeID.

members.name: access
members.documentation: access : readOnly; readWrite, locked, replicationTarget

members.name: name
members.documentation: New name for the clone.

members.name: newAccountID
members.documentation: Account ID for the new volume.

members.name: newSize
members.documentation: New size Total size of the volume, in bytes. Size is rounded up to the neares 1MB size.

members.name: attributes
members.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

members.name: asyncHandle
members.documentation: A value returned from an asynchronous method call.

members.name: groupCloneID
members.documentation: Unique ID of the new group clone.

members.name: members
members.documentation: List of volumeIDs for the source and destination volume pairs.

members.name: asyncHandle
members.documentation: ID of the async process to be checked for completion.

members.name: key
members.documentation: Opaque key uniquely identifying the session.

members.name: url
members.documentation: URL to access the node's web server

members.name: asyncHandle
members.documentation: ID of the async process to be checked for completion.

members.name: key
members.documentation: Opaque key uniquely identifying the session.

members.name: url
members.documentation: URL to access the node's web server

types.name: VolumeAccessGroup
documentation: A volume access group is a useful way of grouping volumes and initiators together for ease of management.
Volume Access Group Limits:
- A volume access group can contain up to sixty-four initiator IQNs.
- An initiator can only belong to only one volume access group.
- A volume access group can contain up to two thousand volumes.
- Each volume access group can belong to a maximum of four other volume access groups.

members.name: volumeAccessGroupID
members.documentation: Unique ID for this volume access group.

members.name: name
members.documentation: Name of the volume access group.

members.name: initiators
members.documentation: List of unique initiator names belonging to the volume access group.

members.name: volumes
members.documentation: List of volumes belonging to the volume access group.

members.name: volumeAccessGroupID
members.documentation: The ID for the newly-created volume access group.

members.name: volumeAccessGroups
members.documentation: List of volume access groups.

members.name: compression
members.documentation: The amount of space being saved by compressing data on a single volume. Stated as a ratio where "1" means data has been stored without being compressed.

members.name: deduplication
members.documentation: The amount of space being saved on a single volume by not duplicating data. Stated as a ratio.

members.name: thinProvisioning
members.documentation: The ratio of space used to the amount of space allocated for storing data. Stated as a ratio.

members.name: timestamp
members.documentation: The last time efficiency data was collected after Garbage Collection (GC). ISO 8601 data string.

members.name: missingVolumes
members.documentation: The volumes that could not be queried for efficiency data. Missing volumes can be caused by GC being less than hour old, temporary network loss or restarted services since the GC cycle.

members.name: volumeAccessGroupLunAssignments
members.documentation: List of all physical Fibre Channel ports, or a port for a single node.

methods.name: AddAccount
documentation: Used to add a new account to the system.
New volumes can be created under the new account.
The CHAP settings specified for the account applies to all volumes owned by the account.

params.name: username
documentation: Unique username for this account.
(May be 1 to 64 characters in length).

params.name: initiatorSecret
documentation: CHAP secret to use for the initiator.
Should be 12-16 characters long and impenetrable.
The CHAP initiator secrets must be unique and cannot be the same as the target CHAP secret.
If not specified, a random secret is created.

params.name: targetSecret
documentation: CHAP secret to use for the target (mutual CHAP authentication).
Should be 12-16 characters long and impenetrable.
The CHAP target secrets must be unique and cannot be the same as the initiator CHAP secret.
If not specified, a random secret is created.

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: GetAccountByID
methods.documentation: Returns details about an account, given its AccountID.

params.name: accountID
params.documentation: Specifies the account for which details are gathered.

methods.name: GetAccountByName
methods.documentation: Returns details about an account, given its Username.

params.name: username
params.documentation: Username for the account.

methods.name: ListAccounts
methods.documentation: Returns the entire list of accounts, with optional paging support.

params.name: startAccountID
documentation: Starting AccountID to return.
If no Account exists with this AccountID,
the next Account by AccountID order is used as the start of the list.
To page through the list, pass the AccountID of the last Account in the previous response + 1

params.name: limit
params.documentation: Maximum number of AccountInfo objects to return.

methods.name: ModifyAccount
documentation: Used to modify an existing account.
When locking an account, any existing connections from that account are immediately terminated.
When changing CHAP settings, any existing connections continue to be active,
and the new CHAP values are only used on subsequent connection or reconnection.

params.name: accountID
params.documentation: AccountID for the account to modify.

params.name: username
params.documentation: Change the username of the account to this value.

params.name: status
params.documentation: Status of the account.

params.name: initiatorSecret
documentation: CHAP secret to use for the initiator.
Should be 12-16 characters long and impenetrable.

params.name: targetSecret
documentation: CHAP secret to use for the target (mutual CHAP authentication).
Should be 12-16 characters long and impenetrable.

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: RemoveAccount
documentation: Used to remove an existing account.
All Volumes must be deleted and purged on the account before it can be removed.
If volumes on the account are still pending deletion, RemoveAccount cannot be used until DeleteVolume to delete and purge the volumes.

params.name: accountID
params.documentation: AccountID for the account to remove.

methods.name: GetAccountEfficiency
methods.documentation: GetVolumeAccessGroupEfficiency is used to retrieve efficiency information about a volume access group. Only the volume access group provided as parameters in this API method is used to compute the capacity.

params.name: accountID
params.documentation: Specifies the volume account for which capacity is computed.

methods.name: GetClusterCapacity
documentation: Return the high-level capacity measurements for an entire cluster.
The fields returned from this method can be used to calculate the efficiency rates that are displayed in the Element User Interface.

methods.name: GetClusterInfo
methods.documentation: Return configuration information about the cluster.

methods.name: GetClusterVersionInfo
documentation: Return information about the Element software version running on each node in the cluster.
Information about the nodes that are currently in the process of upgrading software is also returned.

methods.name: GetLimits
methods.documentation: Retrieves the limit values set by the API

methods.name: ListEvents
methods.documentation: Returns events detected on the cluster, sorted from oldest to newest.

methods.name: ListClusterFaults
methods.documentation: Gets the list of cluster faults

methods.name: ClearClusterFaults
methods.documentation: ClearClusterFaults is used to clear information about both current faults that are resolved as well as faults that were previously detected and resolved can be cleared.

params.name: faultTypes
documentation: Determines the types of faults cleared:
current: Faults that are currently detected and have not been resolved.
resolved: Faults that were previously detected and resolved.
all: Both current and resolved faults are cleared. The fault status can be determined by the "resolved" field of the fault object.

methods.name: GetClusterConfig
documentation: The GetClusterConfig API method is used to return information about the cluster configuration this node uses to communicate with the cluster it is a part of.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.

methods.name: GetClusterFullThreshold
documentation: GetClusterFullThreshold is used to view the stages set for cluster fullness levels. All levels are returned when this method is entered.

methods.name: ModifyClusterFullThreshold
documentation: ModifyClusterFullThreshold is used to change the level at which an event is generated when the storage cluster approaches the capacity utilization requested. The number entered in this setting is used to indicate the number of node failures the system is required to recover from. For example, on a 10 node cluster, if you want to be alerted when the system cannot recover from 3 nodes failures, enter the value of "3". When this number is reached, a message alert is sent to the Event Log in the Cluster Management Console.

params.name: stage2AwareThreshold

deprecated.message: Use stage3BlockThresholdPercent for Oxygen (8.0) and greater.

params.documentation: Number of nodes worth of capacity remaining on the cluster that triggers a notification.

params.name: stage3BlockThresholdPercent
params.documentation: Percent below "Error" state to raise a cluster "Warning" alert.

params.name: maxMetadataOverProvisionFactor
params.documentation: A value representative of the number of times metadata space can be over provisioned relative to the amount of space available. For example, if there was enough metadata space to store 100 TiB of volumes and this number was set to 5, then 500 TiB worth of volumes could be created.

methods.name: GetClusterMasterNodeID
documentation: GetClusterMasterNodeID is used to return the ID of the node that can perform cluster-wide administration tasks and holds the storage virtual IP (SVIP) and management virtual IP (MVIP).

methods.name: GetClusterStats
documentation: GetClusterStats is used to return high-level activity measurements for the cluster. Values returned are cumulative from the creation of the cluster.

methods.name: CreateCluster
documentation: The CreateCluster method is used to initialize the node in a cluster that has ownership of the "mvip" and "svip" addresses. Each new cluster is initialized using the MIP of the first node in the cluster. This method also automatically adds all the nodes being configured into the cluster. The method is used only once each time a new cluster is initialized.

Note: You need to log into the node that is used as the master node for the cluster. Once logged in, run the GetBootstrapConfig method on the node to get the IP addresses for the rest of the nodes that you want to include in the cluster. Then run the CreateCluster method.

params.name: mvip
params.documentation: Floating (virtual) IP address for the cluster on the management network.

params.name: svip
params.documentation: Floating (virtual) IP address for the cluster on the storage (iSCSI) network.

params.name: repCount
params.documentation: Number of replicas of each piece of data to store in the cluster. Valid value is "2".

params.name: username
params.documentation: User name for the cluster admin.

params.name: password
params.documentation: Initial password for the cluster admin account.

params.name: nodes
params.documentation: CIP/SIP addresses of the initial set of nodes making up the cluster. This node's IP must be in the list.

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: ListClusterAdmins
documentation: ListClusterAdmins returns the list of all cluster administrators for the cluster. There can be several cluster administrators that have different levels of permissions. There can be only one primary cluster administrator in the system. The primary Cluster Admin is the administrator that was created when the cluster was created. LDAP administrators can also be created when setting up an LDAP system on the cluster.

methods.name: AddClusterAdmin
documentation: AddClusterAdmin adds a new Cluster Admin. A Cluster Admin can be used to manage the cluster via the API and management tools. Cluster Admins are completely separate and unrelated to standard tenant accounts.

Each Cluster Admin can be restricted to a sub-set of the API. SolidFire recommends using multiple Cluster Admins for different users and applications. Each Cluster Admin should be given the minimal permissions necessary to reduce the potential impact of credential compromise.

params.name: username
params.documentation: Unique username for this Cluster Admin.

params.name: password
params.documentation: Password used to authenticate this Cluster Admin.

params.name: access
params.documentation: Controls which methods this Cluster Admin can use. For more details on the levels of access, see "Access Control" in the Element API Guide.

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: ModifyClusterAdmin
documentation: ModifyClusterAdmin is used to change the settings for a Cluster Admin or LDAP Cluster Admin. Access for the administrator Cluster Admin account cannot be changed.

params.name: clusterAdminID
params.documentation: ClusterAdminID for the Cluster Admin or LDAP Cluster Admin to modify.

params.name: password
params.documentation: Password used to authenticate this Cluster Admin.

params.name: access
params.documentation: Controls which methods this Cluster Admin can use. For more details on the levels of access, see "Access Control" in the Element API Guide.

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: RemoveClusterAdmin
documentation: RemoveClusterAdmin is used to remove a Cluster Admin. The "admin" Cluster Admin cannot be removed.

params.name: clusterAdminID
params.documentation: ClusterAdminID for the Cluster Admin to remove.

methods.name: SetClusterConfig
documentation: The SetClusterConfig API method is used to set the configuration this node uses to communicate with the cluster it is associated with. To see the states in which these objects can be modified see Cluster Object on page 109. To display the current cluster interface settings for a node, run the GetClusterConfig API method.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.

params.name: cluster
params.documentation: Objects that are changed for the cluster interface settings. Only the fields you want changed need to be added to this method as objects in the "cluster" parameter.

methods.name: GetSnmpACL
documentation: GetSnmpACL is used to return the current SNMP access permissions on the cluster nodes.

methods.name: SetSnmpACL
documentation: SetSnmpACL is used to configure SNMP access permissions on the cluster nodes. The values set with this interface apply to all nodes in the cluster, and the values that are passed replace, in whole, all values set in any previous call to SetSnmpACL. Also note that the values set with this interface replace all "network" or "usmUsers" values set with the older SetSnmpInfo.

params.name: networks
params.documentation: List of networks and what type of access they have to the SNMP servers running on the cluster nodes. See SNMP Network Object for possible "networks" values. REQUIRED if SNMP v# is disabled.

params.name: usmUsers
params.documentation: List of users and the type of access they have to the SNMP servers running on the cluster nodes. REQUIRED if SNMP v3 is enabled.

methods.name: GetSnmpTrapInfo
documentation: GetSnmpTrapInfo is used to return current SNMP trap configuration information.

methods.name: SetSnmpTrapInfo
documentation: SetSnmpTrapInfo is used to enable and disable the generation of SolidFire SNMP notifications (traps) and to specify the set of network host computers that are to receive the notifications. The values passed with each SetSnmpTrapInfo method replaces all values set in any previous method to SetSnmpTrapInfo.

params.name: trapRecipients
params.documentation: List of hosts that are to receive the traps generated by the Cluster Master. At least one object is required if any one of the trap types is enabled.

params.name: clusterFaultTrapsEnabled
params.documentation: If "true", when a cluster fault is logged a corresponding solidFireClusterFaultNotification is sent to the configured list of trap recipients.

params.name: clusterFaultResolvedTrapsEnabled
params.documentation: If "true", when a cluster fault is logged a corresponding solidFireClusterFaultResolvedNotification is sent to the configured list of trap recipients.

params.name: clusterEventTrapsEnabled
params.documentation: If "true", when a cluster fault is logged a corresponding solidFireClusterEventNotification is sent to the configured list of trap recipients.

methods.name: EnableSnmp
documentation: EnableSnmp is used to enable SNMP on the cluster nodes. The values set with this interface apply to all nodes in the cluster, and the values that are passed replace, in whole, all values set in any previous call to EnableSnmp.

params.name: snmpV3Enabled
params.documentation: If set to "true", then SNMP v3 is enabled on each node in the cluster. If set to "false", then SNMP v2 is enabled.

methods.name: DisableSnmp
documentation: DisableSnmp is used to disable SNMP on the cluster nodes.

methods.name: GetSnmpInfo
documentation: GetSnmpInfo is used to return the current simple network management protocol (SNMP) configuration information.

Note: GetSnmpInfo will be available for Element OS 8 and prior releases. It will be deprecated after Element OS 8. There are two new SNMP API methods that you should migrate over to. They are GetSnmpState and GetSnmpACL. Please see details in this document for their descriptions and usage.

methods.name: SetSnmpInfo
documentation: SetSnmpInfo is used to configure SNMP v2 and v3 on the cluster nodes. The values set with this interface apply to all nodes in the cluster, and the values that are passed replace, in whole, all values set in any previous call to SetSnmpInfo.

Note: EnableSnmp and SetSnmpACL methods can be used to accomplish the same results as SetSnmpInfo. SetSnmpInfo will no longer be available after the Element 8 release. Please use EnableSnmp and SetSnmpACL in the future.

params.name: networks
params.documentation: List of networks and what type of access they have to the SNMP servers running on the cluster nodes. See SNMP Network Object for possible "networks" values. SNMP v2 only.

params.name: enabled
params.documentation: If set to "true", then SNMP is enabled on each node in the cluster.

params.name: snmpV3Enabled
params.documentation: If set to "true", then SNMP v3 is enabled on each node in the cluster.

params.name: usmUsers
params.documentation: If SNMP v3 is enabled, this value must be passed in place of the "networks" parameter. SNMP v3 only.

methods.name: GetSnmpState
documentation: GetSnmpState is used to return the current state of the SNMP feature.
Note: GetSnmpState is new for Element OS 8. Please use this method and SetSnmpACL to migrate your SNMP functionality in the future.

methods.name: ListSyncJobs
documentation: ListSyncJobs is used to return information about synchronization jobs that are running on a SolidFire cluster. Synchronization jobs that are returned with this method are, "slice," "clone" and "remote."

methods.name: GetAPI
documentation: Retrieves the current version of the API and a list of all supported versions.

methods.name: GetNtpInfo
documentation: GetNtpInfo is used to return the current network time protocol (NTP) configuration information.

methods.name: SetNtpInfo
documentation: SetNtpInfo is used to configure the NTP on cluster nodes. The values set with this interface apply to all nodes in the cluster. The nodes can only be configured as a server where a host is selected to administrate the networking and/or a broadcast client where each host sends each message to each peer.

params.name: servers
params.documentation: List of NTP servers to add to each node's NTP configuration.

params.name: broadcastclient
params.documentation: Enable every node in the cluster as a broadcase client.

methods.name: GetClusterState
documentation:
The GetClusterState method is used to indicate if a node is part of a cluster or not. The three states are:
Available: Node has not been configured with a cluster name.
Pending: Node is pending for a specific named cluster and can be added.
Active: Node is active and a member of a cluster and may not be added to another cluster.

methods.name: GetCurrentClusterAdmin
documentation: GetCurrentClusterAdmin returns information for the current primary cluster administrator. The primary Cluster Admin was ncreated when the cluster was created.

methods.name: CreateClusterSupportBundle
documentation: CreateClusterSupportBundle is used to gather support bundles from all the nodes in a cluster. When the bundle has been successfully created, the bundle is stored on the node as a tar.gz file.

params.name: allowIncomplete
params.documentation: Allows the script to continue to run if bundles cannot be gathered from one or more of the nodes.

params.name: bundleName
params.documentation: Unique name for each support bundle created. If no name is provided, then 'supportbundle' and the node name is used as a file name.

params.name: extraArgs
params.documentation: This parameter is fed to the sf_make_support_bundle script. Should be used only at the request of SolidFire Support.

params.name: mvip
documentation: The mvip of the cluster. Bundles will be gathered from all nodes in the cluster.
REQUIRED if 'nodes' are not specified.

params.name: nodes
documentation: The IP addresses of the nodes from which to gather bundles. Use either 'nodes' or 'mvip', but not both to specify which nodes to gather from.
REQUIRED if 'nodes' are not specified.

params.name: password
documentation: The cluster password. Note: This password will be visible as text when entered.

params.name: username
documentation: The admin user name. Any level of 'admin' can be used.

methods.name: CreateSupportBundle
documentation: CreateSupportBundle is used to create a support bundle file under the node's directory. When the bundle has been successfully created, the bundle is stored on the node as a tar.gz file.

params.name: bundleName
params.documentation: Unique name for each support bundle created. If no name is provided, then 'supportbundle' and the node name is used as a file name.

params.name: extraArgs
params.documentation: This parameter is fed to the sf_make_support_bundle script. Should be used only at the request of SolidFire Support.

params.name: timeoutSec
documentation: The number of seconds to let the support bundle script run before timing out and stopping. Default is 1500 seconds.

methods.name: DeleteAllSupportBundles
documentation: DeleteAllSupportBundles is used to delete all support bundles generated with the CreateSupportBundle API method.

methods.name: EnableEncryptionAtRest
documentation: The EnableEncryptionAtRest method is used to enable the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) 256-bit encryption at rest on the cluster so that the cluster can manage the encryption key used for the drives on each node. This feature is not enabled by default. Enabling this operation allows the cluster to automatically manage encryption keys internally for the drives on each node in the cluster. Nodes do not store the keys to unlock drives and the keys are never passed over the network. Two nodes participating in a cluster are required to access the key to disable encryption on a drive. The encryption management does not affect performance or efficiency on the cluster. If an encryption-enabled drive or node is removed from the cluster with the API, all data is secure erased and any data left on the drive cannot be read or accessed.

Enabling or disabling encryption should be performed when the cluster is running and in a healthy state. Encryption can be enabled or disabled at your discretion and can be performed as often as you need.
Note: This process is asynchronous and returns a response before encryption is enabled. The GetClusterInfo method can be used to poll the system to see when the process has completed.

methods.name: DisableEncryptionAtRest
documentation: The DisableEncryptionAtRest method is used to remove the encryption that was previously applied to the cluster using the EnableEncryptionAtRest method.

Enabling or disabling encryption should be performed when the cluster is running and in a healthy state. Encryption can be enabled or disabled at your discretion and can be performed as often as you need.
Note: This process is asynchronous and returns a response before encryption is disabled. The GetClusterInfo method can be used to poll the system to see when the process has completed.

params.name: force
params.documentation: Force must always be true when called on a cluster connection.

methods.name: GetAsyncResult
documentation: Used to retrieve the result of asynchronous method calls.
Some method calls are long running and do not complete when the initial response is sent.
To obtain the result of the method call, polling with GetAsyncResult is required.
GetAsyncResult returns the overall status of the operation (in progress, completed, or error) in a standard fashion,
but the actual data returned for the operation depends on the original method call and the return data is documented with each method.
The result for a completed asynchronous method call can only be retrieved once.
Once the final result has been returned, later attempts returns an error.

params.name: asyncHandle
params.documentation: A value that was returned from the original asynchronous method call.

methods.name: AddDrives
documentation: AddDrives is used to add one or more available drives to the cluster enabling the drives to host a portion of the cluster's data.

When a new drive is made available to the cluster, either through a newly added node or by being inserted into an existing node, it is marked as "available" and must be added via AddDrives before it is utilized.
Use the ListDrives method to display drives that are "available" to be added.
When multiple drives are being added, it is more efficient to add them in a single AddDrives method rather than multiple individual methods with a single drive.
This reduces the amount of data balancing that must occur to even out the storage load on the cluster.
When adding a drive, the system automatically determines the "type" of drive it should be.
The method returns immediately, however it may take some period of time for the data in the cluster to be fully rebalanced using the newly added drives.
As the new drive(s) are syncing on the system, you can use the "ListSyncJobs" method to see how the drive(s) are being rebalanced and the progress of adding the new drive.

params.name: drives
params.documentation: List of drives to add to the cluster.

methods.name: ListDrives
documentation: ListDrives is used to return the list of the drives that exist in the cluster's active nodes. Drives that have been added as volume metadata or block drives, as well as drives that have not been added and are available are returned.

methods.name: GetDriveConfig
documentation: GetDriveConfig is used to display drive information for expected slice and block drive counts as well as the number of slices and block drives that are currently connected to the node.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.
