methods.name: GetDriveHardwareInfo
methods.documentation: GetDriveHardwareInfo returns all the hardware info for the given drive. This generally includes manufacturers, vendors, versions, and other associated hardware identification information.

params.name: driveID
params.documentation: DriveID for the drive information requested. DriveIDs can be obtained via the "ListDrives" method.

methods.name: GetDriveStats
documentation: GetDriveStats return high-level activity measurements for a single drive. Values are cumulative from the addition of the drive to the cluster. Some values are specific to Block Drives. Statistical data may not be returned for both block and metadata drives when running this method.
For more information on which drive type returns which data, see Response Example (Block Drive) and Response Example (Volume Metadata Drive) in the SolidFire API guide.

params.name: driveID
params.documentation: Specifies the drive for which statistics are gathered.

methods.name: SecureEraseDrives
documentation: SecureEraseDrives is used to remove any residual data from drives that have a status of "available." For example, when replacing a drive at its end-of-life that contained sensitive data.

It uses a Security Erase Unit command to write a predetermined pattern to the drive and resets the encryption key on the drive. The method may take up to two minutes to complete, so it is an asynchronous method.
The GetAsyncResult method can be used to check on the status of the secure erase operation.
Use the "ListDrives" method to obtain the driveIDs for the drives you want to secure erase.

params.name: drives
params.documentation: List of driveIDs to secure erase.

methods.name: RemoveDrives
documentation: RemoveDrives is used to pro-actively remove drives that are part of the cluster. For example, when reducing cluster capacity or preparing to replace drives at their end-of-life.
Using the RemoveDrives method ensures that any data on the drives to be removed is migrated to other drives in the cluster prior to removal. This is an asynchronous method.

Depending on the total capacity of the drives being removed, it may take several minutes to migrate all of the data. The "GetAsyncResult" method can be used to check on the status of the remove operation.
When multiple drives are being removed, it is more efficient to remove them in a single RemoveDrives method rather than multiple individual methods with a single drive.
This reduces the amount of data balancing that must occur to even out the storage load on the cluster.

Drives with a "failed" status can also be removed using RemoveDrives. When a drive with a "failed" status is removed it is not returned to an "available" or "active" status. The drive is unavailable for use in the cluster.
Use the "ListDrives" method to obtain the driveIDs for the drives you want to remove.

params.name: drives
params.documentation: List of driveIDs to remove from the cluster.

methods.name: ListFibreChannelPortInfo
documentation: The ListFibreChannelPortInfo is used to return information about the Fibre Channel ports. The API method is intended for use on individual nodes; userid and password is required for access to individual Fibre Channel nodes. However, this method can be used on the cluster if the force=true parameter is included in the method call. When used on the cluster, all Fibre Channel interfaces are listed.

methods.name: ListNodeFibreChannelPortInfo
documentation: The ListNodeFibreChannelPortInfo is used to return information about the Fibre Channel ports. The API method is intended for use on individual nodes; userid and password is required for access to individual Fibre Channel nodes. However, this method can be used on the cluster if the force=true parameter is included in the method call. When used on the cluster, all Fibre Channel interfaces are listed.

params.name: force
params.documentation: Specify force=true to call method on all member nodes of the cluster.

methods.name: ListFibreChannelSessions
documentation: The ListFibreChannelSessions is used to return information about the active Fibre Channel sessions on a cluster.

methods.name: AddLdapClusterAdmin
documentation: AddLdapClusterAdmin is used to add a new LDAP Cluster Admin. An LDAP Cluster Admin can be used to manage the cluster via the API and management tools. LDAP Cluster Admins are completely separate and unrelated to standard tenant accounts.
An LDAP group that has been defined in Active Directory can also be added using this API method. The access level that is given to the group will be passed to the individual users in the LDAP group.

params.name: username
params.documentation: The distinguished user name for the new LDAP cluster admin.

params.name: access
params.documentation: Controls which methods this Cluster Admin can use. For more details on the levels of access, see the Access Control appendix in the SolidFire API Reference.

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: TestLdapAuthentication
documentation: The TestLdapAuthentication is used to verify the currently enabled LDAP authentication configuration settings are correct. If the configuration settings are correct, the API call returns a list of the groups the tested user is a member of.

params.name: username
params.documentation: The username to be tested.

params.name: password
params.documentation: The password for the username to be tester.

params.name: ldapConfiguration
params.documentation: An ldapConfiguration object to be tested. If this parameter is provided, the API call will test the provided configuration even if LDAP authentication is currently disabled.

methods.name: GetLdapConfiguration
documentation: The GetLdapConfiguration is used to get the LDAP configuration currently active on the cluster.

methods.name: EnableLdapAuthentication
documentation: The EnableLdapAuthentication method is used to configure an LDAP server connection to use for LDAP authentication to a SolidFire cluster. Users that are members on the LDAP server can then log in to a SolidFire storage system using their LDAP authentication userid and password.

params.name: authType
documentation: Identifies which user authentcation method will be used.
Must be one of the following:
DirectBind
SearchAndBind (default)

params.name: groupSearchBaseDN
documentation: The base DN of the tree to start the group search (will do a subtree search from here).

params.name: groupSearchCustomFilter
documentation: REQUIRED for CustomFilter
For use with the CustomFilter search type, an LDAP filter to use to return the DNs of a user's groups.
The string can have placeholder text of %USERNAME% and %USERDN% to be replaced with their username and full userDN as needed.

params.name: groupSearchType
documentation: Controls the default group search filter used, can be one of the following:
NoGroups: No group support.
ActiveDirectory: (default) Nested membership of all of a user's AD groups.
MemberDN: MemberDN style groups (single-level).

params.name: searchBindDN
documentation: REQUIRED for SearchAndBind
A fully qualified DN to log in with to perform an LDAP search for the user (needs read access to the LDAP directory).

params.name: searchBindPassword
documentation: REQUIRED for SearchAndBind
The password for the searchBindDN account used for searching.

params.name: serverURIs
documentation: A list of LDAP server URIs (examples: "ldap://1.2.3.4" and ldaps://1.2.3.4:123")

params.name: userDNTemplate
documentation: REQUIRED for DirectBind
A string that is used to form a fully qualified user DN.
The string should have the placeholder text "%USERNAME%" which will be replaced with the username of the authenticating user.

params.name: userSearchBaseDN
documentation: REQUIRED for SearchAndBind
The base DN of the tree used to start the search (will do a subtree search from here).

params.name: userSearchFilter
documentation: REQUIRED for SearchAndBind.
The LDAP filter to use.
The string should have the placeholder text "%USERNAME%" which will be replaced with the username of the authenticating user.
Example: (&(objectClass=person) (sAMAccountName=%USERNAME%)) will use the sAMAccountName field in Active Directory to match the nusername entered at cluster login.

methods.name: DisableLdapAuthentication
documentation: The DisableLdapAuthentication method is used disable LDAP authentication and remove all LDAP configuration settings. This call will not remove any configured cluster admin accounts (user or group). However, those cluster admin accounts will no longer be able to log in.

methods.name: GetLoginSessionInfo
documentation: GetLoginSessionInfo is used to return the period of time a log in authentication is valid for both log in shells and the TUI.

methods.name: SetLoginSessionInfo
documentation: SetLoginSessionInfo is used to set the period of time a log in authentication is valid. After the log in period elapses without activity on the system the authentication will expire. New log in credentials will be required for continued access to the cluster once the timeout period has elapsed.

params.name: timeout
params.documentation: Cluster authentication expiration period. Formatted in HH:mm:ss. For example: 01:30:00, 00:90:00, and 00:00:5400 can all be used to equal a 90 minute timeout period. Default is 30 minutes.

methods.name: GetRemoteLoggingHosts
documentation: GetRemoteLoggingHosts is used to retrieve the current list of log servers.

methods.name: SetRemoteLoggingHosts
documentation: RemoteLoggingHosts is used to configure remote logging from the nodes in the storage cluster to a centralized log server or servers. Remote logging is performed over TCP using the default port 514. This API does not add to the existing logging hosts. Rather, it replaces what currently exists with new values specified by this API method. You can use the GetRemoteLoggingHosts to determine what the current logging hosts are and then use the SetRemoteLoggingHosts to set the desired list of current and new logging hosts.

params.name: remoteHosts
params.documentation: List of hosts to send log messages to.

methods.name: ListNetworkInterfaces
documentation: The ListNetworkInterfaces API method is used to return information about each network interface on a node. The API method is intended for use on individual nodes.

params.name: force
documentation: This parameter is necessary when calling this API method against a cluster connection.
Possible values:
true: information about all network interfaces in the cluster will be returned.
false: no information will be returned.

methods.name: ListClusterNetworkInterfaces
documentation: The ListClusterNetworkInterfaces API method is used to return information about each network interface on the nodes in a cluster. You must pass the force=true parameter when this method is called against a cluster. When used on the cluster, all interfaces on all nodes are listed.

params.name: force
documentation: This parameter is necessary when calling this API method against a cluster connection.
Possible values:
true: information about all network interfaces in the cluster will be returned.
false: no information will be returned.

methods.name: ListPendingNodes
documentation: Gets the list of pending nodes.
Pending nodes are running and configured to join the cluster, but have not been added via the AddNodes method.

methods.name: AddNodes

params.name: pendingNodes
params.documentation: List of PendingNodeIDs for the Nodes to be added. You can obtain the list of Pending Nodes via the ListPendingNodes method.

documentation: AddNodes is used to add one or more new nodes to the cluster. When a node is not configured and starts up for the first time you are prompted to configure the node. Once a node is configured it is registered as a "pending node" with the cluster.

Adding a node to a cluster that has been set up for virtual networking will require a sufficient number of virtual storage IP addresses to allocate a virtual IP to the new node. If there are no virtual IP addresses available for the new node, the AddNode operation will not complete successfully. Use the "ModifyVirtualNetwork" method to add more storage IP addresses to your virtual network.

The software version on each node in a cluster must be compatible. Run the "ListAllNodes" API to see what versions of software are currently running on the cluster nodes. For an explanation of software version compatibility, see "Node Versioning and Compatibility" in the Element API guide.
Once a node has been added, the drives on the node are made available and can then be added via the "AddDrives" method to increase the storage capacity of the cluster.
Note: It may take several seconds after adding a new Node for it to start up and register the drives as being available.

methods.name: RemoveNodes

params.name: nodes
params.documentation: List of NodeIDs for the nodes to be removed.

documentation: RemoveNodes is used to remove one or more nodes that should no longer participate in the cluster. Before removing a node, all drives it contains must first be removed with "RemoveDrives" method. A node cannot be removed until the RemoveDrives process has completed and all data has been migrated away from the node.
Once removed, a node registers itself as a pending node and can be added again, or shut down which removes it from the "Pending Node" list.

methods.name: GetNetworkConfig
documentation: The GetNetworkConfig API method is used to display the network configuration information for a node.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.

methods.name: SetNetworkConfig

params.name: network
params.documentation: Objects that will be changed for the node network settings.

documentation: The "SetNetworkConfig" method is used to set the network configuration for a node. To see the states in which these objects can be modified, see "Network Object for 1G and 10G Interfaces" on page 109 of the Element API. To display the current network settings for a node, run the "GetNetworkConfig" method.
WARNING! Changing the "bond-mode" on a node can cause a temporary loss of network connectivity. Caution should be taken when using this method.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.

methods.name: GetConfig
documentation: The GetConfig API method is used to retrieve all the configuration information for the node. This one API method includes the same information available in both "GetClusterConfig" and "GetNetworkConfig" methods.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.

methods.name: GetBootstrapConfig
documentation: GetBootstrapConfig returns the cluster name and node name from the bootstrap configuration file. This API method should be performed on an individual node before it has been configured into a cluster. The resulting information from this method is used in the Cluster Configuration UI when the cluster is eventually created.

methods.name: GetNodeStats

params.name: nodeID
params.documentation: Specifies the node for which statistics are gathered.

documentation: GetNodeStats is used to return the high-level activity measurements for a single node.

methods.name: ListNodeStats
documentation: ListNodeStats is used to return the high-level activity measurements for all nodes in a cluster.

methods.name: GetPendingOperation
documentation: GetPendingOperation is used to detect an operation on a node that is currently in progress. This method can also be used to report back when an operation has completed.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.

methods.name: ListClusterPairs
documentation: ListClusterPairs is used to list all of the clusters a cluster is paired with. Clusters listed in the return for this method include active and pending pairings. Information about each cluster includes statistics about the current pairing, as well as the connectivity, and latency (in milliseconds) of the cluster pairing.

methods.name: ListActivePairedVolumes
documentation: ListActivePairedVolumes is used to list all of the active paired volumes paired with a volume. Volumes listed in the return for this method include volumes with active and pending pairings.

methods.name: StartClusterPairing
documentation: StartClusterPairing is used to create an encoded key from a cluster that is used to pair with another cluster. The key created from this API method is used in the CompleteClusterPairing API method to establish a cluster pairing. A cluster can be paired with a maximum of four other SolidFire clusters.

methods.name: StartVolumePairing

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the volume on which to start the pairing process.

params.name: mode
documentation: The mode of the volume on which to start the pairing process. The mode can only be set if the volume is the source volume.
Possible values:
Async: Waits for system to acknowledge that data is stored on source before writing to the target.
Sync: Does not wait for data transmission acknowledgment from source to begin writing data to the target.
SnapshotsOnly: Only snapshots created on the source cluster will be replicated. Active writes from the source volume will not be replicated.

StartVolumePairing is used to create an encoded key from a volume that is used to pair with another volume. The key created from this API method is used in the CompleteVolumePairing API method to establish a volume pairing.

methods.name: CompleteClusterPairing
documentation: CompleteClusterPairing is the second step in the cluster pairing process. It uses the encoded key received from the StartClusterPairing API method to complete the cluster pairing process.

methods.name: CompleteVolumePairing

params.name: volumePairingKey
params.documentation: The key returned from the StartVolumePairing API method.

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: The ID of volume on which to complete the pairing process.

documentation: CompleteVolumePairing is used to complete the pairing of two volumes.

methods.name: RemoveClusterPair
documentation: RemoveClusterPair is used to disconnect the open connections between two clusters created by cluster pairing.
Note: Before a cluster pair can be removed, all volume pairing to the clusters must be removed with the RemoveVolumePair API method.

methods.name: RemoveVolumePair

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: ID of the volume on which to stop the replication process.

documentation: RemoveVolumePair is used to remove the remote pairing between two volumes. When the volume pairing information is removed, data is no longer replicated to or from the volume. This method should be run on both the source and target volumes that are paired together.

methods.name: ModifyVolumePair

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: Identification number of the volume to be modified.

params.name: pausedManual
documentation: Valid values that can be entered:
true: to pause volume replication.
false: to restart volume replication.
If no value is specified, no change in replication is performed.

params.name: mode
documentation: Volume replication mode.
Possible values:
Async: Waits for system to acknowledge that data is stored on source before writing to the target.
Sync: Does not wait for data transmission acknowledgment from source to begin writing data to the target.
SnapshotsOnly: Only snapshots created on the source cluster will be replicated. Active writes from the source volume will not be replicated.
ModifyVolumePair is used to pause or restart replication between a pair of volumes.

methods.name: ListProtocolEndpoints
documentation: Gets protocol endpoints in the system
If protocolEndpointIDs isn't specified all protocol endpoints
are returned. Else the supplied protocolEndpointIDs are.

methods.name: ListServices
documentation: List the services in the cluster.

methods.name: CreateSnapshot
documentation: CreateSnapshot is used to create a point-in-time copy of a volume.
A snapshot can be created from any volume or from an existing snapshot.
Note: Creating a snapshot is allowed if cluster fullness is at stage 2 or 3.
Snapshots are not created when cluster fullness is at stage 4 or 5.

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: ID of the volume image from which to copy.

params.name: snapshotID
documentation: Unique ID of a snapshot from which the new snapshot is made.
The snapshotID passed must be a snapshot on the given volume.
If a SnapshotID is not provided, a snapshot is created from the volume's active branch.

params.name: name
documentation: A name for the snapshot.
If no name is provided, the date and time the snapshot was taken is used.

params.name: enableRemoteReplication
params.documentation: Identifies if snapshot is enabled for remote replication.

params.name: retention
documentation: The amount of time the snapshot will be retained. Enter in HH:mm:ss

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: DeleteSnapshot
documentation: DeleteSnapshot is used to delete a snapshot.
A snapshot that is currently the "active" snapshot cannot be deleted.
You must rollback and make another snapshot "active" before the current snapshot can be deleted.
To rollback a snapshot, use RollbackToSnapshot.

params.name: snapshotID
params.documentation: The ID of the snapshot to delete.

methods.name: ListSnapshots
documentation: ListSnapshots is used to return the attributes of each snapshot taken on the volume.

params.name: volumeID
documentation: The volume to list snapshots for.
If not provided, all snapshots for all volumes are returned.

methods.name: ModifySnapshot
documentation: ModifySnapshot is used to change the attributes currently assigned to a snapshot.
Use this API method to enable the snapshots created on the Read/Write (source) volume to be remotely replicated to a target SolidFire storage system.

params.name: snapshotID
params.documentation: ID of the snapshot.

params.name: expirationTime
params.documentation: Use to set the time when the snapshot should be removed.

params.name: enableRemoteReplication
documentation: Use to enable the snapshot created to be replicated to a remote SolidFire cluster.
Possible values:
true: the snapshot will be replicated to remote storage.
false: Default. No replication.

methods.name: RollbackToSnapshot
documentation: RollbackToSnapshot is used to make an existing snapshot the "active" volume image. This method creates a new
snapshot from an existing snapshot. The new snapshot becomes "active" and the existing snapshot is preserved until
it is manually deleted. The previously "active" snapshot is deleted unless the parameter saveCurrentState is set with
a value of "true."
Note: Creating a snapshot is allowed if cluster fullness is at stage 2 or 3.
Snapshots are not created when cluster fullness is at stage 4 or 5.

params.name: volumeID
documentation: VolumeID for the volume.

params.name: snapshotID
documentation: ID of a previously created snapshot on the given volume.

params.name: saveCurrentState
documentation: true: The previous active volume image is kept.
false: (default) The previous active volume image is deleted.

params.name: name
documentation: Name for the snapshot. If no name is given, then the name of the snapshot being rolled back to is used with
"-copy" appended to the end of the name.

params.name: attributes
documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format

methods.name: CreateGroupSnapshot
documentation: CreateGroupSnapshot is used to create a point-in-time copy of a group of volumes.
The snapshot created can then be used later as a backup or rollback to ensure the data on the group of volumes is consistent for the point in time in which the snapshot was created.
Note: Creating a group snapshot is allowed if cluster fullness is at stage 2 or 3.
Snapshots are not created when cluster fullness is at stage 4 or 5.

params.name: volumes
params.documentation: Unique ID of the volume image from which to copy.

params.name: name
documentation: A name for the snapshot.
If no name is provided, the date and time the snapshot was taken is used.

params.name: enableRemoteReplication
params.documentation: Identifies if snapshot is enabled for remote replication.

params.name: retention
documentation: The amount of time the snapshot will be retained. Enter in HH:mm:ss

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: DeleteGroupSnapshot
documentation: DeleteGroupSnapshot is used to delete a group snapshot.
The saveMembers parameter can be used to preserve all the snapshots that
were made for the volumes in the group but the group association will be removed.

params.name: groupSnapshotID
params.documentation: Unique ID of the group snapshot.

params.name: saveMembers
documentation: true: Snapshots are kept, but group association is removed.
false: The group and snapshots are deleted.

methods.name: ListGroupSnapshots
documentation: ListGroupSnapshots is used to return information about all group snapshots that have been created.

params.name: volumeID
documentation: An array of unique volume IDs to query.
If this parameter is not specified, all group snapshots on the cluster will be included.

methods.name: ModifyGroupSnapshot
documentation: ModifyGroupSnapshot is used to change the attributes currently assigned to a group snapshot.

params.name: groupSnapshotID
params.documentation: ID of the snapshot.

params.name: expirationTime
params.documentation: Use to set the time when the snapshot should be removed.

params.name: enableRemoteReplication
documentation: Use to enable the snapshot created to be replicated to a remote SolidFire cluster.
Possible values:
true: the snapshot will be replicated to remote storage.
false: Default. No replication.

methods.name: RollbackToGroupSnapshot
documentation: RollbackToGroupSnapshot is used to roll back each individual volume in a snapshot group to a copy of their individual snapshots.
Note: Creating a snapshot is allowed if cluster fullness is at stage 2 or 3.
Snapshots are not created when cluster fullness is at stage 4 or 5.

params.name: groupSnapshotID
documentation: Unique ID of the group snapshot.

params.name: saveCurrentState
documentation: true: The previous active volume image is kept.
false: (default) The previous active volume image is deleted.

params.name: name
documentation: Name for the snapshot. If no name is given, then the name of the snapshot being rolled back to is used with
"-copy" appended to the end of the name.

params.name: attributes
documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format

methods.name: GetSchedule
documentation: GetSchedule is used to return information about a scheduled snapshot that has been created. You can see information about a specified schedule if there are many snapshot schedules in the system. You can include more than one schedule with this method by specifying additional scheduleIDs to the parameter.

params.name: scheduleID
documentation: Unique ID of the schedule or multiple schedules to display

methods.name: ListSchedules
documentation: ListSchedule is used to return information about all scheduled snapshots that have been created.

methods.name: CreateSchedule
documentation: CreateSchedule is used to create a schedule that will autonomously make a snapshot of a volume at a defined interval.
The snapshot created can be used later as a backup or rollback to ensure the data on a volume or group of volumes is consistent for the point in time in which the snapshot was created.
Note: Creating a snapshot is allowed if cluster fullness is at stage 2 or 3. Snapshots are not created when cluster fullness is at stage 4 or 5.

params.name: attributes
documentation: The "frequency" object is returned in "attributes" to indicate the frequency at which the snapshot will be made.
Valid values for "frequency" are:
Days of Week
Days of Month
Time Interval

params.name: hours
documentation: Number of hours between snapshots or hour at which the snapshot will occur in "Days of Week", or "Days of Month" mode.
Valid values: 0 - 24

params.name: minutes
documentation: Number of minutes between snapshots or minute at which the snapshot will occur in "Days of Week", or "Days of Month" mode.
Valid values: 0 - 59

params.name: paused
documentation: Indicates if the schedule should be paused or not.

params.name: recurring
documentation: Indicates if the schedule will be recurring or not.

params.name: scheduleName
documentation: Unique name for the schedule.

params.name: scheduleType
documentation: Indicates the type of schedule to create.
Valid value is:
snapshot

params.name: scheduleInfo
documentation: An object of schedule information about how the snapshot should be created at each scheduled interval.
volumeID - The ID of the volume to be included in the snapshot. (Integer)
volumes - A list of volume IDs to be included in the group snapshot. (Array of Integers)
name - The snapshot name to be used. (String)
enableRemoteReplication - Indicates if the snapshot should be included in remote replication. (Boolean)
retention - The amount of time the snapshot will be retained in HH:mm:ss. (String)

params.name: startingDate
documentation: Time after which the schedule will be run. If not set the schedule starts immediately. Formatted in UTC time.

params.name: monthdays
documentation: The days of the month that a snapshot will be made.
Valid values: 1 - 31

params.name: weekdays
documentation: Day of the week the snapshot is to be created.
Required values:
day: 0 - 6 (Sunday - Saturday)
offset: 1

methods.name: ModifySchedule
documentation: ModifySchedule is used to change the intervals at which a scheduled snapshot occurs. This allows for adjustment to the snapshot frequency and retention.

params.name: attributes
documentation: The "frequency" object is returned in "attributes" to indicate the frequency at which the snapshot will be made.
Valid values for "frequency" are:
Days of Week
Days of Month
Time Interval

params.name: hours
documentation: Number of hours between snapshots or hour at which the snapshot will occur in "Days of Week", or "Days of Month" mode.
Valid values: 0 - 24

params.name: minutes
documentation: Number of minutes between snapshots or minute at which the snapshot will occur in "Days of Week", or "Days of Month" mode.
Valid values: 0 - 59

params.name: monthdays
documentation: The days of the month that a snapshot will be made.
Valid values: 1 - 31

params.name: paused
documentation: Indicates if the schedule should be paused or not.

params.name: recurring
documentation: Indicates if the schedule will be recurring or not.

params.name: runNextInterval
documentation: Use to choose to run the schedule when the scheduler the next time the scheduler is active. When set to "true", the schedule will run the next time the scheduler is active and then reset back to "false".

params.name: scheduleID
documentation: Unique ID of the schedule.

params.name: scheduleInfo
documentation: An object of schedule information about how the snapshot should be created at each scheduled interval.
volumeID - The ID of the volume to be included in the snapshot. (Integer)
volumes - A list of volume IDs to be included in the group snapshot. (Array of Integers)
name - The snapshot name to be used. (String)
enableRemoteReplication - Indicates if the snapshot should be included in remote replication. (Boolean)
retention - The amount of time the snapshot will be retained in HH:mm:ss. (String)

params.name: scheduleName
documentation: Unique name for the schedule.

params.name: scheduleType
documentation: Only "snapshot" is supported at this time.

params.name: startingDate
documentation: Indicates the date the first time the schedule began or will begin.

params.name: toBeDeleted
documentation: Indicates if the schedule is marked for deletion.

params.name: weekdays
documentation: Day of the week the snapshot is to be created. The day of the week starts at Sunday with the value of "0" and an offset of "1." Monday has a value of "1" with an offset of "1", etc.

methods.name: GetRawStats
documentation: The GetRawStats call is used by SolidFire engineering to troubleshoot new features. The data returned from GetRawStats is not documented, it changes frequently, and is not guaranteed to be accurate. It is not recommended to ever use GetRawStats for collecting performance data or any other management integration with a SolidFire cluster.

The data returned from GetRawStats changes frequently, and is not guaranteed to accurately show performance from the system. It is not recommended to ever use GetRawStats for collecting performance data or any other management integration with a SolidFire cluster.

methods.name: GetCompleteStats
documentation: The GetCompleteStats API method is used by SolidFire engineering to troubleshoot new features. The data returned from GetCompleteStats is not documented, changes frequently, and is not guaranteed to be accurate. It is not recommended to ever use GetCompleteStats for collecting performance data or any other management integration with a SolidFire cluster.

The data returned from GetCompleteStats changes frequently, and is not guaranteed to accurately show performance from the system. It is not recommended to ever use GetCompleteStats for collecting performance data or any other management integration with a SolidFire cluster.

methods.name: CreateStorageContainer
methods.documentation: Creates a new VVols storage container.

params.name: name
params.documentation: Name of the storage container.

methods.name: DeleteStorageContainers
methods.documentation: Deletes a storage container from the system.

params.name: storageContainerIDs
params.documentation: list of storageContainerID of the storage container to delete.

methods.name: ModifyStorageContainer
methods.documentation: Modifies an existing storage container.

methods.name: ListStorageContainers
methods.documentation: Gets information for all storage containers currently in the system.

params.name: storageContainerIDs
params.documentation: List of storage containers to get

methods.name: ListTests
documentation: The ListTests API method is used to return the tests that are available to run on a node.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.

methods.name: ListUtilities
documentation: The ListUtilities API method is used to return the tests that are available to run on a node.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.

methods.name: TestConnectEnsemble
documentation: The TestConnectEnsemble API method is used to verify connectivity with a sepcified database ensemble. By default it uses the ensemble for the cluster the node is associated with. Alternatively you can provide a different ensemble to test connectivity with.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.

params.name: ensemble
params.documentation: A comma-separated list of ensemble node CIPs for connectivity testing

methods.name: TestConnectMvip
documentation: The TestConnectMvip API method is used to test the management connection to the cluster. The test pings the MVIP and executes a simple API method to verify connectivity.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.

params.name: mvip
params.documentation: Optionally, use to test the management connection of a different MVIP. This is not needed to test the connection to the target cluster.

methods.name: TestConnectSvip
documentation: The TestConnectSvip API method is used to test the storage connection to the cluster. The test pings the SVIP using ICMP packets and when successful connects as an iSCSI initiator.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.

params.name: svip
params.documentation: Optionally, use to test the storage connection of a different SVIP. This is not needed to test the connection to the target cluster.

methods.name: TestPing
documentation: The TestPing API method is used to validate the connection to all nodes in the cluster on both 1G and 10G interfaces using ICMP packets. The test uses the appropriate MTU sizes for each packet based on the MTU settings in the network configuration.
Note: This method is available only through the per-node API endpoint 5.0 or later.

params.name: attempts
params.documentation: Specifies the number of times the system should repeat the test ping. Default is 5.

params.name: hosts
params.documentation: Specify address or hostnames of devices to ping.

params.name: totalTimeoutSec
params.documentation: Specifies the length of time the ping should wait for a system response before issuing the next ping attempt or ending the process.

params.name: packetSize
params.documentation: Specify the number of bytes to send in the ICMP packet sent to each IP. Number be less than the maximum MTU specified in the network configuration.

params.name: pingTimeoutMsec
params.documentation: Specify the number of milliseconds to wait for each individual ping response. Default is 500ms.

methods.name: ListVirtualNetworks
documentation: ListVirtualNetworks is used to get a list of all the configured virtual networks for the cluster. This method can be used to verify the virtual network settings in the cluster.
This method does not require any parameters to be passed. But, one or more VirtualNetworkIDs or VirtualNetworkTags can be passed in order to filter the results.

params.name: virtualNetworkID
params.documentation: Network ID to filter the list for a single virtual network

params.name: virtualNetworkTag
params.documentation: Network Tag to filter the list for a single virtual network

params.name: virtualNetworkIDs
params.documentation: NetworkIDs to include in the list.

params.name: virtualNetworkTags
params.documentation: Network Tags to include in the list.

methods.name: AddVirtualNetwork
documentation: AddVirtualNetwork is used to add a new virtual network to a cluster configuration. When a virtual network is added, an interface for each node is created and each will require a virtual network IP address. The number of IP addresses specified as a parameter for this API method must be equal to or greater than the number of nodes in the cluster. Virtual network addresses are bulk provisioned by SolidFire and assigned to individual nodes automatically. Virtual network addresses do not need to be assigned to nodes manually.
Note: The AddVirtualNetwork method is used only to create a new virtual network. If you want to make changes to a virtual network, please use the ModifyVirtualNetwork method.

params.name: virtualNetworkTag
params.documentation: A unique virtual network (VLAN) tag. Supported values are 1 to 4095 (the number zero (0) is not supported).

params.name: name
params.documentation: User defined name for the new virtual network.

params.name: addressBlocks
documentation: Unique Range of IP addresses to include in the virtual network.
Attributes for this parameter are:
start: start of the IP address range. (String)
size: numbre of IP addresses to include in the block. (Integer)

params.name: netmask
documentation: Unique netmask for the virtual network being created.

params.name: svip
documentation: Unique storage IP address for the virtual network being created.

params.name: attributes
documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: ModifyVirtualNetwork
documentation: ModifyVirtualNetwork is used to change various attributes of a VirtualNetwork object. This method can be used to add or remove address blocks, change the netmask IP, or modify the name or description of the virtual network.
Note: This method requires either the VirtualNetworkID or the VirtualNetworkTag as a parameter, but not both.

params.name: virtualNetworkID
params.documentation: Unique identifier of the virtual network to modify. This is the virtual network ID assigned by the SolidFire cluster.

params.name: virtualNetworkTag
params.documentation: Network Tag that identifies the virtual network to modify.

params.name: name
params.documentation: New name for the virtual network.

params.name: addressBlocks
documentation: New addressBlock to set for this Virtual Network object. This may contain new address blocks to add to the existing object or it may omit unused address blocks that need to be removed. Alternatively, existing address blocks may be extended or reduced in size. The size of the starting addressBlocks for a Virtual Network object can only be increased, and can never be decreased.
Attributes for this parameter are:
start: start of the IP address range. (String)
size: numbre of IP addresses to include in the block. (Integer)

params.name: netmask
documentation: New netmask for this virtual network.

params.name: svip
documentation: The storage virtual IP address for this virtual network. The svip for Virtual Network cannot be changed. A new Virtual Network must be created in order to use a different svip address.

params.name: attributes
documentation: A new list of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: RemoveVirtualNetwork
documentation: RemoveVirtualNetwork is used to remove a previously added virtual network.
Note: This method requires either the VirtualNetworkID of the VirtualNetworkTag as a parameter, but not both.

params.name: virtualNetworkID
params.documentation: Network ID that identifies the virtual network to remove.

params.name: virtualNetworkTag
params.documentation: Network Tag that identifies the virtual network to remove.

methods.name: CreateVirtualVolume
documentation: CreateVirtualVolume is used to create a new (empty) Virtual Volume on the cluster.
When the volume is created successfully it is available for connection via PE.

params.name: name
documentation: Name of the Virtual Volume.
Not required to be unique, but it is recommended.
May be 1 to 64 characters in length.

params.name: storageContainerID
params.documentation: UUID for the Storage Container of this volume.

params.name: virtualVolumeType
params.documentation: VMW_TYPE value for this volume.

params.name: totalSize
params.documentation: Total size of the volume, in bytes. Size is rounded up to the nearest 1MB size.

params.name: qos
documentation: Initial quality of service settings for this volume.
Volumes created without specified QoS values are created with the default values for QoS.
Default values for a volume can be found by running the GetDefaultQoS method.

params.name: metadata
documentation: List of name/value pairs to save in the volume's metadata.

methods.name: DeleteVirtualVolumes
documentation: DeleteVirtualVolume marks an active volume for deletion.
It is purged (permanently deleted) after the cleanup interval elapses.
After making a request to delete a volume, any active iSCSI connections to the volume is immediately terminated and no further connections are allowed while the volume is in this state.
It is not returned in target discovery requests.
Any snapshots of a volume that has been marked to delete are not affected.
Snapshots are kept until the volume is purged from the system.
If a volume is marked for deletion, and it has a bulk volume read or bulk volume write operation in progress, the bulk volume operation is stopped.
If the volume you delete is paired with a volume, replication between the paired volumes is suspended and no data is transferred to it or from it while in a deleted state.
The remote volume the deleted volume was paired with enters into a PausedMisconfigured state and data is no longer sent to it or from the deleted volume.
Until the deleted volume is purged, it can be restored and data transfers resumes.
If the deleted volume gets purged from the system, the volume it was paired with enters into a StoppedMisconfigured state and the volume pairing status is removed.
The purged volume becomes permanently unavailable.

params.name: virtualVolumes
params.documentation: The UUID of the volume to delete.

params.name: startVirtualVolumeID
documentation: The ID of the first Virtual Volume to list.
This can be useful for paging results.
By default, this lists all Virtual Volumes.

params.name: limit
documentation: The maximum number of volumes to return from the API.

params.name: virtualVolumeIDs
documentation: List of Virtual Volume IDs to get.

methods.name: ModifyVirtualVolume
documentation: ModifyVirtualVolume is used to modify settings on an existing virtual volume.

params.name: virtualVolumeID
params.documentation: VvolVolumeID for the volume to be modified.

params.name: qos
params.documentation: New quality of service settings for this volume.

params.name: totalSize
documentation: New size of the volume in bytes.
Size is rounded up to the nearest 1MiB size.
This parameter can only be used to *increase* the size of a volume.

methods.name: ModifyVirtualVolumeMetadata
documentation: ModifyVirtualVolumeMetadata is used to selectively modify the VVol metadata.

params.name: virtualVolumeID
params.documentation: VvolVolumeID for the volume to be modified.

methods.name: QueryVirtualVolumeMetadata
documentation: QueryVirtualVolumeMetadata returns a list of VVols matching a metadata query.

methods.name: CloneVirtualVolume
documentation: CloneVirtualVolume is used to execute a VMware Virtual Volume clone.

params.name: virtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the Virtual Volume to clone.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name for the newly-created volume.

params.name: qos
params.documentation: New quality of service settings for this volume.

methods.name: FastCloneVirtualVolume
documentation: FastCloneVirtualVolume is used to execute a VMware Virtual Volume fast clone.

params.name: virtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the Virtual Volume to clone.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name for the newly-created volume.

params.name: qos
params.documentation: New quality of service settings for this volume.

methods.name: PrepareVirtualSnapshot
documentation: PrepareVirtualSnapshot is used to set up VMware Virtual Volume snapshot.

params.name: virtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the Virtual Volume to clone.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name for the newly-created volume.

params.name: writableSnapshot
params.documentation: Will the snapshot be writable?

methods.name: SnapshotVirtualVolume
documentation: SnapshotVirtualVolume is used to take a VMware Virtual Volume snapshot.

params.name: virtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the Virtual Volume to clone.

params.name: timeout
params.documentation: Number of seconds to complete or fail.

methods.name: RollbackVirtualVolume
documentation: RollbackVirtualVolume is used to restore a VMware Virtual Volume snapshot.

params.name: srcVirtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the Virtual Volume snapshot.

params.name: dstVirtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the Virtual Volume to restore to.

methods.name: GetVirtualVolumeAllocatedBitmap
documentation: GetVirtualVolumeAllocatedBitmap returns a b64-encoded block of data
representing a bitmap where non-zero bits indicate the allocation of a
segment (LBA range) of the volume.

params.name: virtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the Virtual Volume.

params.name: segmentStart
params.documentation: Byte offset.

params.name: segmentLength
params.documentation: Byte length adjusted to end on a chunk boundary.

params.name: chunkSize
params.documentation: Number of bytes represented by one bit in the bitmap.

methods.name: GetVirtualVolumeUnsharedBitmap
documentation: GetVirtualVolumeAllocatedBitmap returns a b64-encoded block of data
representing a bitmap where non-zero bits indicate that data is not the same
between two volumes for a common segment (LBA range) of the volumes.

params.name: virtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the Virtual Volume.

params.name: baseVirtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the Virtual Volume to compare against.

params.name: segmentStart
params.documentation: Byte offset.

params.name: segmentLength
params.documentation: Byte length adjusted to end on a chunk boundary.

params.name: chunkSize
params.documentation: Number of bytes represented by one bit in the bitmap.

methods.name: GetVirtualVolumeUnsharedChunks
documentation: GetVirtualVolumeAllocatedBitmap scans a VVol segment and returns the number of
chunks not shared between two volumes. This call will return results in less
than 30 seconds. If the specified VVol and the base VVil are not related, an
error is thrown. If the offset/length combination is invalid or out fo range
an error is thrown.

params.name: virtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the Virtual Volume.

params.name: baseVirtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the Virtual Volume to compare against.

params.name: segmentStart
params.documentation: Start Byte offset.

params.name: segmentLength
params.documentation: Length of the scan segment in bytes.

params.name: chunkSize
params.documentation: Number of bytes represented by one bit in the bitmap.

methods.name: CopyDiffsToVirtualVolume
documentation: CopyDiffsToVirtualVolume is a three-way merge function.

params.name: virtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the snapshot Virtual Volume.

params.name: baseVirtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the base Virtual Volume.

params.name: dstVirtualVolumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the Virtual Volume to be overwritten.

methods.name: CreateVirtualVolumeHost
documentation: CreateVirtualVolumeHost creates a new ESX host.

params.name: virtualVolumeHostID
params.documentation: The GUID of the ESX host.

params.name: clusterID
params.documentation: The GUID of the ESX Cluster.

params.name: visibleProtocolEndpointIDs
params.documentation: A list of PEs the host is aware of.

params.name: hostAddress
params.documentation: IP or DNS name for the host.

methods.name: ListVirtualVolumeHosts
documentation: ListVirtualVolumeHosts returns a list of known ESX hosts.

methods.name: ModifyVirtualVolumeHost
documentation: ModifyVirtualVolumeHost changes an existing ESX host.

params.name: virtualVolumeHostID
params.documentation: The GUID of the ESX host.

params.name: clusterID
params.documentation: The GUID of the ESX Cluster.

params.name: visibleProtocolEndpointIDs
params.documentation: A list of PEs the host is aware of.

params.name: initiatorNames
params.documentation: List of iSCSI initiator IQNs for the host.

params.name: hostAddress
params.documentation: IP or DNS name for the host.

methods.name: GetVirtualVolumeTaskUpdate
documentation: GetVirtualVolumeTaskUpdate checks the status of a VVol Async Task.

params.name: virtualVolumeTaskID
params.documentation: The UUID of the VVol Task.

methods.name: ListVirtualVolumeTasks
documentation: ListVirtualVolumeTasks returns a list of VVol Async Tasks.

methods.name: CancelVirtualVolumeTask
documentation: CancelVirtualVolumeTask attempts to cancel the VVol Async Task.

params.name: virtualVolumeTaskID
params.documentation: The UUID of the VVol Task to cancel.

methods.name: BindVirtualVolumes
documentation: BindVirtualVolume binds a VVol with a Host.

params.name: virtualVolumeIDs
params.documentation: The UUID of the VVol to bind.

params.name: virtualVolumeHostID
params.documentation: The UUID of the ESX host.

params.name: bindContext
params.documentation: Normal or Start?

methods.name: ListVirtualVolumeBindings
documentation: ListVirtualVolumeBindings returns a list of VVol bindings.

methods.name: UnbindVirtualVolumes
documentation: UnbindGetVirtualVolume removes the VVol <-> Host binding.

params.name: unbindContext
params.documentation: Normal, Start, or End?

methods.name: ModifyVasaProviderInfo
documentation: Update the Vasa Provider info

params.name: keystore
params.documentation: Signed SSL certificate for the Vasa Provider

params.name: vasaProviderID
params.documentation: UUID identifying the vasa provider

methods.name: GetVasaProviderInfo
documentation: Gets the Vasa Provider info

methods.name: CloneVolume
documentation: CloneVolume is used to create a copy of the volume.
This method is asynchronous and may take a variable amount of time to complete.
The cloning process begins immediately when the CloneVolume request is made and is representative of the state of the volume when the API method is issued.
GetAsyncResults can be used to determine when the cloning process is complete and the new volume is available for connections.
ListSyncJobs can be used to see the progress of creating the clone.
Note: The initial attributes and quality of service settings for the volume are inherited from the volume being cloned.
If different settings are required, they can be changed via ModifyVolume.
Note: Cloned volumes do not inherit volume access group memberships from the source volume.

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the volume to clone.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name for the newly-created volume.

params.name: newAccountID
documentation: AccountID for the owner of the new volume.
If unspecified, the AccountID of the owner of the volume being cloned is used.

params.name: newSize
documentation: New size of the volume, in bytes.
May be greater or less than the size of the volume being cloned.
If unspecified, the clone's volume size will be the same as the source volume.
Size is rounded up to the nearest 1 MiB.

params.name: access
documentation: Access settings for the new volume.
readOnly: Only read operations are allowed.
readWrite: Reads and writes are allowed.
locked: No reads or writes are allowed.
replicationTarget: Identify a volume as the target volume for a paired set of volumes. If the volume is not paired, the access status is locked.
If unspecified, the access settings of the clone will be the same as the source.

params.name: snapshotID
documentation: ID of the snapshot to use as the source of the clone.
If unspecified, the clone will be created with a snapshot of the active volume.

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: CloneMultipleVolumes
documentation: CloneMultipleVolumes is used to create a clone of a group of specified volumes. A consistent set of characteristics can be assigned to a group of multiple volume when they are cloned together.

If groupSnapshotID is going to be used to clone the volumes in a group snapshot, the group snapshot must be created first using the CreateGroupSnapshot API method or the SolidFire Element WebUI. Using groupSnapshotID is optional when cloning multiple volumes.
Note: Cloning multiple volumes is allowed if cluster fullness is at stage 2 or 3. Clones are not created when cluster fullness is at stage 4 or 5.

params.name: volumes
params.documentation: Array of Unique ID for each volume to include in the clone with optional parameters. If optional parameters are not specified, the values will be inherited from the source volumes.

params.name: access
documentation: New default access method for the new volumes if not overridden by information passed in the volumes array.
readOnly: Only read operations are allowed.
readWrite: Reads and writes are allowed.
locked: No reads or writes are allowed.
replicationTarget: Identify a volume as the target volume for a paired set of volumes. If the volume is not paired, the access status is locked.
If unspecified, the access settings of the clone will be the same as the source.

params.name: groupSnapshotID
params.documentation: ID of the group snapshot to use as a basis for the clone.

params.name: newAccountID
params.documentation: New account ID for the volumes if not overridden by information passed in the volumes array.

methods.name: CopyVolume
methods.documentation: Copies one volume to another.

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: Source volume to copy.

params.name: dstVolumeID
params.documentation: Destination volume for the copy.

params.name: snapshotID
params.documentation: Snapshot ID of the source volume to create the copy from.

methods.name: CancelClone
methods.documentation: Cancels a currently running clone operation.

methods.name: CreateVolume
documentation: CreateVolume is used to create a new (empty) volume on the cluster.
When the volume is created successfully it is available for connection via iSCSI.

params.name: name
documentation: Name of the volume.
Not required to be unique, but it is recommended.
May be 1 to 64 characters in length.

params.name: accountID
params.documentation: AccountID for the owner of this volume.

params.name: totalSize
params.documentation: Total size of the volume, in bytes. Size is rounded up to the nearest 1MB size.

params.name: enable512e
params.documentation: Should the volume provides 512-byte sector emulation?

params.name: qos
documentation: Initial quality of service settings for this volume.
Volumes created without specified QoS values are created with the default values for QoS.
Default values for a volume can be found by running the GetDefaultQoS method.

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: DeleteVolume
documentation: DeleteVolume marks an active volume for deletion.
It is purged (permanently deleted) after the cleanup interval elapses.
After making a request to delete a volume, any active iSCSI connections to the volume is immediately terminated and no further connections are allowed while the volume is in this state.
It is not returned in target discovery requests.
Any snapshots of a volume that has been marked to delete are not affected.
Snapshots are kept until the volume is purged from the system.
If a volume is marked for deletion, and it has a bulk volume read or bulk volume write operation in progress, the bulk volume operation is stopped.
If the volume you delete is paired with a volume, replication between the paired volumes is suspended and no data is transferred to it or from it while in a deleted state.
The remote volume the deleted volume was paired with enters into a PausedMisconfigured state and data is no longer sent to it or from the deleted volume.
Until the deleted volume is purged, it can be restored and data transfers resumes.
If the deleted volume gets purged from the system, the volume it was paired with enters into a StoppedMisconfigured state and the volume pairing status is removed.
The purged volume becomes permanently unavailable.

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the volume to delete.

methods.name: GetDefaultQoS
documentation: GetDefaultQoS is used to retrieve the default QoS values that are set for a volume if QoS is not supplied.

methods.name: GetVolumeStats
documentation: GetVolumeStats is used to retrieve high-level activity measurements for a single volume.
Values are cumulative from the creation of the volume.

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: Specifies the volume for which statistics is gathered.

methods.name: GetVolumeEfficiency
documentation: GetVolumeEfficiency is used to retrieve information about a volume.
Only the volume given as a parameter in this API method is used to compute the capacity.

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: Specifies the volume for which capacity is computed.

methods.name: ListBulkVolumeJobs
documentation: ListBulkVolumeJobs is used to return information about each bulk volume read or write operation that is occurring in the system.

methods.name: ListActiveVolumes
documentation: ListActiveVolumes is used to return the list of active volumes currently in the system.
The list of volumes is returned sorted in VolumeID order and can be returned in multiple parts (pages).

params.name: startVolumeID
documentation: The ID of the first volume to list.
This can be useful for paging results.
By default, this starts at the lowest VolumeID.

params.name: limit
documentation: The maximum number of volumes to return from the API.

methods.name: ListDeletedVolumes
documentation: ListDeletedVolumes is used to return the entire list of volumes that have been marked for deletion and is purged from the system.

methods.name: ListISCSISessions
methods.documentation: ListISCSISessions is used to return iSCSI connection information for volumes in the cluster.

methods.name: ListVolumes
documentation: The ListVolumes method is used to return a list of volumes that are in a cluster.
You can specify the volumes you want to return in the list by using the available parameters.

params.name: startVolumeID
documentation: The ID of the first volume to list.
This can be useful for paging results.
By default, this starts at the lowest VolumeID.

params.name: limit
documentation: The maximum number of volumes to return from the API.

params.name: volumeStatus
documentation: If specified, filter to only volumes with the provided status.
By default, list all volumes.

params.name: accounts
documentation: If specified, only fetch volumes which belong to the provided accounts.
By default, list volumes for all accounts.

params.name: isPaired
documentation: If specified, only fetch volumes which are paired (if true) or non-paired (if false).
By default, list all volumes regardless of their pairing status.

params.name: volumeIDs
documentation: If specified, only fetch volumes specified in this list.
This option cannot be specified if startVolumeID, limit, or accounts option is specified.

methods.name: ListVolumesForAccount
documentation: ListVolumesForAccount returns the list of active AND (pending) deleted volumes for an account.

params.name: accountID
params.documentation: The ID of the account to list the volumes for.

params.name: startVolumeID
documentation: The ID of the first volume to list.
This can be useful for paging results.
By default, this starts at the lowest VolumeID.

params.name: limit
documentation: The maximum number of volumes to return from the API.

methods.name: ListVolumeStatsByAccount
documentation: ListVolumeStatsByAccount returns high-level activity measurements for every account.
Values are summed from all the volumes owned by the account.

methods.name: ListVolumeStatsByVolume
documentation: ListVolumeStatsByVolume returns high-level activity measurements for every volume, by volume.
Values are cumulative from the creation of the volume.

methods.name: ListVolumeStatsByVolumeAccessGroup
documentation: ListVolumeStatsByVolumeAccessGroup is used to get total activity measurements for all of the volumes that are a member of the specified volume access group(s).

params.name: volumeAccessGroups
documentation: An array of VolumeAccessGroupIDs for which volume activity is returned.
If no VolumeAccessGroupID is specified, stats for all volume access groups is returned.

methods.name: ModifyVolume
documentation: ModifyVolume is used to modify settings on an existing volume.
Modifications can be made to one volume at a time and changes take place immediately.
If an optional parameter is left unspecified, the value will not be changed.
Extending the size of a volume that is being replicated should be done in an order.
The target (Replication Target) volume should first be increased in size, then the source (Read/Write) volume can be resized.
It is recommended that both the target and the source volumes be the same size.
Note: If you change access status to locked or target all existing iSCSI connections are terminated.

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: VolumeID for the volume to be modified.

params.name: accountID
documentation: AccountID to which the volume is reassigned.
If none is specified, the previous account name is used.

params.name: access
documentation: Access allowed for the volume.
readOnly: Only read operations are allowed.
readWrite: Reads and writes are allowed.
locked: No reads or writes are allowed.
replicationTarget: Identify a volume as the target volume for a paired set of volumes. If the volume is not paired, the access status is locked.
If unspecified, the access settings of the clone will be the same as the source.

params.name: setCreateTime
documentation: Identify the time at which the volume was created.

params.name: qos
params.documentation: New quality of service settings for this volume.

params.name: totalSize
documentation: New size of the volume in bytes.
Size is rounded up to the nearest 1MiB size.
This parameter can only be used to *increase* the size of a volume.

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: PurgeDeletedVolume
documentation: PurgeDeletedVolume immediately and permanently purges a volume which has been deleted.
A volume must be deleted using DeleteVolume before it can be purged.
Volumes are purged automatically after a period of time, so usage of this method is not typically required.

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: The ID of the volume to purge.

methods.name: RestoreDeletedVolume
documentation: RestoreDeletedVolume marks a deleted volume as active again.
This action makes the volume immediately available for iSCSI connection.

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: RestoreDeletedVolume

methods.name: StartBulkVolumeRead
documentation: StartBulkVolumeRead is used to initialize a bulk volume read session on a specified volume. Only two bulk volume processes can run simultaneously on a volume. When the session is initialized, data is read from a SolidFire storage volume for the purposes of storing the data on an external backup source. The external data is accessed by a web server running on a SolidFire node. Communications and server interaction information for external data access is passed by a script running on the SolidFire storage system.

At the start of a bulk volume read operation, a snapshot of the volume is made and the snapshot is deleted when the read has completed. You can also read a snapshot of the volume by entering the ID of the snapshot as a parameter. Reading a previous snapshot does not create a new snapshot of the volume, nor does the previous snapshot be deleted when the read completes.

Note: This process creates a new snapshot if the ID of an existing snapshot is not provided. Snapshots can be created if cluster fullness is at stage 2 or 3. Snapshots are not created when cluster fullness is at stage 4 or 5.

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: ID of the volume to be read.

params.name: format
documentation: The format of the volume data. Can be either:
uncompressed: every byte of the volume is returned without any compression.
native: opaque data is returned that is smaller and more efficiently stored and written on a subsequenct bulk volume write.

params.name: snapshotID
documentation: ID of a previously created snapshot used for bulk volume reads. If no ID is entered, a snapshot of the current active volume image is made.

params.name: script
documentation: Executable name of a script. If no script name is given then the key and URL is necessary to access SolidFire nodes. The script is run on the primary node and the key and URL is returned to the script so the local web server can be contacted.

params.name: scriptParameters
documentation: JSON parameters to pass to the script.

params.name: attributes
documentation: JSON attributes for the bulk volume job.

methods.name: StartBulkVolumeWrite
documentation: StartBulkVolumeWrite is used to initialize a bulk volume write session on a specified volume. Only two bulk volume processes can run simultaneously on a volume. When the session is initialized, data can be written to a SolidFire storage volume from an external backup source. The external data is accessed by a web server running on a SolidFire node. Communications and server interaction information for external data access is passed by a script running on the SolidFire storage system.

params.name: volumeID
params.documentation: ID of the volume to be read.

params.name: format
documentation: The format of the volume data. Can be either:
uncompressed: every byte of the volume is returned without any compression.
native: opaque data is returned that is smaller and more efficiently stored and written on a subsequenct bulk volume write.

params.name: script
documentation: Executable name of a script. If no script name is given then the key and URL is necessary to access SolidFire nodes. The script is run on the primary node and the key and URL is returned to the script so the local web server can be contacted.

params.name: scriptParameters
documentation: JSON parameters to pass to the script.

params.name: attributes
documentation: JSON attributes for the bulk volume job.

methods.name: CreateVolumeAccessGroup
documentation: Creates a new volume access group.
The new volume access group must be given a name when it is created.
Entering initiators and volumes are optional when creating a volume access group.
Once the group is created volumes and initiator IQNs can be added.
Any initiator IQN that is successfully added to the volume access group is able to access any volume in the group without CHAP authentication.

params.name: name
documentation: Name of the volume access group.
It is not required to be unique, but recommended.

params.name: initiators
documentation: List of initiators to include in the volume access group.
If unspecified, the access group will start out without configured initiators.

params.name: volumes
documentation: List of volumes to initially include in the volume access group.
If unspecified, the access group will start without any volumes.

params.name: virtualNetworkID
params.documentation: The ID of the SolidFire Virtual Network ID to associate the volume access group with.

params.name: virtualNetworkTags
params.documentation: The ID of the VLAN Virtual Network Tag to associate the volume access group with.

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

methods.name: ListVolumeAccessGroups
documentation: ListVolumeAccessGroups is used to return information about the volume access groups that are currently in the system.

params.name: startVolumeAccessGroupID
documentation: The lowest VolumeAccessGroupID to return.
This can be useful for paging.
If unspecified, there is no lower limit (implicitly 0).

params.name: limit
documentation: The maximum number of results to return.
This can be useful for paging.

methods.name: DeleteVolumeAccessGroup
methods.documentation: Delete a volume access group from the system.

params.name: volumeAccessGroupID
documentation: The ID of the volume access group to delete.

methods.name: ModifyVolumeAccessGroup
documentation: Update initiators and add or remove volumes from a volume access group.
A specified initiator or volume that duplicates an existing volume or initiator in a volume access group is left as-is.
If a value is not specified for volumes or initiators, the current list of initiators and volumes are not changed.
Often, it is easier to use the convenience functions to modify initiators and volumes independently:
AddInitiatorsToVolumeAccessGroup
RemoveInitiatorsFromVolumeAccessGroup
AddVolumesToVolumeAccessGroup
RemoveVolumesFromVolumeAccessGroup

params.name: volumeAccessGroupID
params.documentation: The ID of the volume access group to modify.

params.name: virtualNetworkID
params.documentation: The ID of the SolidFire Virtual Network ID to associate the volume access group with.

params.name: virtualNetworkTags
params.documentation: The ID of the VLAN Virtual Network Tag to associate the volume access group with.

params.name: name
documentation: Name of the volume access group.
It is not required to be unique, but recommended.

params.name: initiators
documentation: List of initiators to include in the volume access group.
If unspecified, the access group's configured initiators will not be modified.

params.name: volumes
documentation: List of volumes to initially include in the volume access group.
If unspecified, the access group's volumes will not be modified.

params.name: attributes
params.documentation: List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.

params.name: initiators

methods.name: GetVolumeAccessGroupEfficiency
methods.documentation: GetVolumeAccessGroupEfficiency is used to retrieve efficiency information about a volume access group. Only the volume access group provided as parameters in this API method is used to compute the capacity.

params.name: volumeAccessGroupID
params.documentation: Specifies the volume access group for which capacity is computed.

methods.name: GetVolumeAccessGroupLunAssignments
methods.documentation: The GetVolumeAccessGroupLunAssignments is used to return information LUN mappings of a specified volume access group.

params.name: volumeAccessGroupID
params.documentation: Unique volume access group ID used to return information.

methods.name: ModifyVolumeAccessGroupLunAssignments
documentation: The ModifytVolumeAccessGroupLunAssignments is used to define custom LUN assignments for specific volumes. Only LUN values set on the lunAssignments parameter will be changed in the volume access group. All other LUN assignments will remain unchanged.

LUN assignment values must be unique for volumes in a volume access group. An exception will be seen if LUN assignments are duplicated in a volume access group. However, the same LUN values can be used again in different volume access groups.
Note: Correct LUN values are 0 - 16383. An exception will be seen if an incorrect LUN value is passed. None of the specified LUN assignments will be modified if there is an exception.
Caution: If a LUN assignment is changed for a volume with active I/O, the I/O could be disrupted. Changes to the server configuration may be required in order to change volume LUN assignments.

params.name: volumeAccessGroupID
params.documentation: Unique volume access group ID for which the LUN assignments will be modified.

params.name: lunAssignments
params.documentation: The volume IDs with new assigned LUN values.
